The plot summary is an overview of the film's main events, so avoid minute details such as dialogue, scene-by-scene breakdowns, and technical detail.-->
==Voice cast== <!--In-universe details about the characters belong in the plot section according to WP:FILMCAST guidelines, please reconsider adding such material to this section as it will most likely be reverted.--> [[File:Atlantis Milo kida production.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A penciled production sketch showing a man (Milo) on the left embracing a woman (Kida) on the right. A horizontal line is visible on the bottom of the page depicting a reference line for the CinemaScope frame of the drawing.|Production sketch of Milo and Kida. Milo's character design was based in part on sketches of the film's language consultant, [[Marc Okrand]].]] * [[Michael J. Fox]] as Milo James Thatch, a [[Linguistics|linguist]] and [[Cartography|cartographer]] at the Smithsonian who was recruited to decipher The Shepherd's Journal while directing an expedition to Atlantis. Kirk Wise, one of the directors, said that they chose Fox for the role because they felt he gave his character his own personality and made them more believable on screen. Fox said that voice acting was much easier than his past experience with live action because he did not have to worry about what he looked like in front of a camera while delivering his lines.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 0:20‚Äì0:56]]</ref> The directors mentioned that Fox was also offered a role for ''[[Titan A.E.]]''; he allowed his son to choose which film he would work on, and he chose ''Atlantis''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,106688,00.html|title=Movie Preview: ''Atlantis'' (2001)|date=May 14, 2001|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=September 1, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116184524/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C106688%2C00.html|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Viewers have noted similarities between Milo and the film's language consultant, [[Marc Okrand]], who developed the [[Atlantean language]] used in the film. Okrand stated that Milo's supervising animator, [[John Pomeroy]], sketched him, claiming not to know how a linguist looked or acted.<ref name="Language">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2001-05-24-atlantis-lingo.htm|title=New Movie Trek for Wordsmith|first=Susan|last=Wloszczyna|date=May 24, 2001|work=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514011113/http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2001-05-24-atlantis-lingo.htm|archivedate=May 14, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[James Garner]] as Commander Lyle Tiberius Rourke, the leader of the band of mercenaries, for the Atlantean expedition. Wise chose Garner because of his previous experience with [[action film]]s, especially [[War film|war]] and [[Western (genre)|Western]] films, and said the role "fits him like a glove". When asked if he would be interested in the role, Garner replied: "I'd do it in a heartbeat."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 3:50‚Äì4:31]]</ref> * [[Cree Summer]] as Kidagakash "Kida" Nedakh, the Princess of Atlantis. Kida's supervising animator, Randy Haycock, stated that Summer was very "intimidating" when he first met her; this influenced how he wanted Kida to look and act on screen when she meets Milo.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 2:32‚Äì2:50]]</ref> Natalie Strom provided dialogue for Kida as a young child. * [[Don Novello]] as Vincenzo "Vinny" Santorini, an [[Italians|Italian]] [[Demolition|demolitions expert]]. Kirk Wise and [[Russ Edmonds]], Vinny's supervising animator, noted Novello's unique ability to [[improvisation|improvise]] dialogue. Edmonds recalled, "[Novello] would look at the sheet, and he would read the line that was written once, and he would never read it again! And we never used a written line, it was improvs, the whole movie."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 7:18‚Äì7:47]]</ref> * [[Phil Morris (actor)|Phil Morris]] as Doctor Joshua Strongbear Sweet, a [[medic]] of [[African American]] and [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] descent. Sweet's supervising animator, [[Ron Husband]], indicated that one of the challenges was animating Sweet in sync with Morris' rapid line delivery while keeping him believable. Morris stated that this character was extreme, with "no middle ground"; he mentioned, "When he was happy, he was ''really'' happy, and when he's solemn, he's ''real'' solemn."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 8:20‚Äì9:13]]</ref> * [[Claudia Christian]] as Lieutenant Helga Sinclair, Rourke's German second-in-command and lieutenant. Christian described her character as "sensual" and "striking". She was relieved when she finally saw what her character looked like, joking, "I'd hate to, you know, go through all this and find out my character is a toad."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 10:18‚Äì10:39]]</ref> * [[Jacqueline Obradors]] as Audrey Rocio Ramirez, a teenage [[Puerto Rican people|Puerto Rican]] [[mechanic]] and the youngest member of the expedition. Obradors said her character made her "feel like a little kid again" and she always hoped her sessions would last longer.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 5:59‚Äì6:07]]</ref> * [[Florence Stanley]] as Wilhelmina Bertha Packard: an elderly, sarcastic, chain-smoking [[Radio|radio operator]]. Stanley felt that Packard was very "cynical" and "secure": "She does her job and when she is not busy she does anything she wants."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 9:38‚Äì9:51]]</ref> * [[David Ogden Stiers]] as Fenton Q. Harcourt, a board member of the [[Smithsonian Institution]] who dismisses Milo's belief in the existence of Atlantis. Stiers previously worked with Michael J. Fox in ''[[Doc Hollywood]]''. He earlier voice-acted for Disney in ''[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]]'' as Cogsworth, ''[[Pocahontas (1995 film)|Pocahontas]]'' as Governor Ratcliffe, and ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]'' as the Archdeacon and would do so again in ''[[Lilo & Stitch]]'' as Jumba. * [[John Mahoney]] as Preston B. Whitmore, an eccentric millionaire who funds the expedition to Atlantis. [[Lloyd Bridges]] was originally cast and recorded as Whitmore, but he died before completing the film. Mahoney's zest and vigor led to Whitmore's personality being reworked for the film.<ref>[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 15.]]</ref> Mahoney stated that doing voice work was "freeing" and allowed him to be "big" and "outrageous" with his character.<ref name="Cast">[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 4:55‚Äì5:07]]</ref> * [[Jim Varney]] as Jebidiah Allardyce "Cookie" Farnsworth, a Western-style [[chuckwagon]] chef. Varney died of lung cancer in February 2000, before the production ended, and the film was dedicated to his memory. Producer Don Hahn was saddened that Varney never saw the finished film, but mentioned that he was shown clips of his character's performance during his site sessions and said, "He loved it." Shawn Keller, supervising animator for Cookie, stated, "It was kind of a sad fact that [Varney] knew that he was not going to be able to see this film before he passed away. He did a bang-up job doing the voice work, knowing the fact that he was never gonna see his last performance."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 10:45‚Äì11:31]]</ref> * [[Corey Burton]] as Ga√´tan "Mole" Moli√®re, a French [[geologist]] who acts like a [[mole (animal)|mole]]. Burton mentioned that finding his performance as Mole was by allowing the character to "leap out" of him while making funny voices. To get into character during his recording sessions, he stated that he would "throw myself into the scene and feel like I'm in this make-believe world".<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 6:55‚Äì7:10]]</ref> * [[Leonard Nimoy]] as Kashekim Nedakh, the King of Atlantis and Kida's father. Michael Cedeno, supervising animator for King Nedakh, was astounded at Nimoy's voice talent, stating that he had "so much rich character" in his performance. As he spoke his lines, Cadeno said the crew would sit there and watch Nimoy in astonishment.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: The Voices of Atlantis'' at 3:00‚Äì3:43]]</ref> * [[Jennifer Seguin]] as Kashem Nedakh, the Queen of Atlantis and Kida's mother.
==Production== ===Development=== [[Image:Carlsbad Caverns rail pic.JPG|240px|thumb|alt=A picture of a partially illuminated underground cave with a jagged rock ceiling and a walkway extended into the cavern.|The production team visited [[Carlsbad Caverns|New Mexico's Carlsbad Caverns]] to get a sense of the underground spaces depicted in the film.]] The idea for ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' was conceived in October 1996 when [[Don Hahn]], [[Gary Trousdale]], [[Kirk Wise]], and Tab Murphy lunched at a Mexican restaurant in [[Burbank, California]]. Having recently completed ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]''<ref name="Kurtti-9">[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 9.]]</ref> the producer and directors wanted to keep the ''Hunchback'' crew together for another film with an [[Adventureland (Disney)|Adventureland]] setting.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: The Journey Begins'' at 0:08‚Äì3:05]]</ref> Drawing inspiration from [[Jules Verne]]'s ''[[A Journey to the Center of the Earth]]'' (1864), they set out to make a film which would fully explore [[Atlantis]] (compared to the brief visit depicted in Verne's novel).<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Story and Editorial: Finding the Story'' at 3:24‚Äì3:57]]</ref> While primarily utilizing the Internet to research the mythology of Atlantis,<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: Creating Mythology'' at 0:30‚Äì1:10]]</ref> the filmmakers became interested in the [[Clairvoyance|clairvoyant]] readings of [[Edgar Cayce]] and decided to incorporate some of his ideas‚Äînotably that of a mother-crystal which provides power, healing, and longevity to the Atlanteans‚Äîinto the story.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: Creating Mythology'' at 3:48‚Äì4:20]]</ref> They also visited museums and old army installations to study the technology of the early 20th century (the film's time period), and traveled 800 feet underground in New Mexico's Carlsbad Caverns to view the subterranean trails which would serve as a model for the approach to Atlantis in the film.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Art Direction: Designing Atlantis'' at 5:42‚Äì9:18]]</ref>
The filmmakers wanted to avoid the common depiction of Atlantis as "crumbled Greek columns underwater", said Wise.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Art Direction: Designing Atlantis'' at 9:30‚Äì9:33]]</ref> "From the get-go, we were committed to designing it top to bottom. Let's get the architectural style, clothing, heritage, customs, how they would sleep, and how they would speak. So we brought people on board who would help us develop those ideas."<ref name="FilmJournal">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000692578|title=Finding ''Atlantis''|first=Peter|last=Henn|date=June 1, 2001|work=[[Film Journal International]]|accessdate=August 30, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116180317/http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000692578|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Art director David Goetz stated, "We looked at [[Mayan architecture]], styles of ancient, unusual architecture from around the world, and the directors really liked the look of Southeast Asian architecture."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Art Direction: Designing Atlantis'' at 9:50‚Äì10:02]]</ref> The team later took ideas from other architectural forms, including [[Cambodian architecture|Cambodian]], [[Indian architecture|Indian]], and [[Architecture in Tibet|Tibetan]] works.<ref name="Kurtti-55">[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 55.]]</ref> Hahn added, "If you take and deconstruct architecture from around the world into one architectural vocabulary, that's what our Atlantis looks like."<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Art Direction: Designing Atlantis'' at 10:37‚Äì10:44]]</ref> The overall design and [[concentric circles|circular]] layout of Atlantis were also based on the writings of [[Plato]],<ref name="Kurtti-55"/> and his quote "in a single day and night of misfortune, the island of Atlantis disappeared into the depths of the sea"<ref>[[#Plato|Plato c. 360 BCE]], [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0180:text=Tim.:section=25c ''Timaeus'', Sections 25c‚Äìd] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317203053/http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0180%3Atext%3DTim.%3Asection%3D25c |date=March 17, 2013 }}. "But at a later time there occurred portentous earthquakes and floods, and one grievous day and night befell them, when the whole body of your warriors was swallowed up by the earth, and the island of Atlantis in like manner was swallowed up by the sea and vanished."</ref> was influential from the beginning of production.<ref name="Kurtti-9"/> The crew wore [[T-shirt]]s which read "ATLANTIS‚ÄîFewer songs, more explosions" due the film's plan as an [[Adventure film|action-adventure]] (unlike previous Disney animated features, which were [[Musical film|musicals]]).<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: The Journey Begins'' at 5:28‚Äì5:40]]</ref>
==== Language ==== [[Image:AtlanteanA.png|thumb|right|alt=A drawing of the Atlantean letter A which is a swirl with a dot in the center.|The Atlantean letter ''A'', created by artist John Emerson. Kirk Wise noted that its design was a treasure map showing the path to the crystal, "The Heart of Atlantis".]] {{Main|Atlantean language}} [[Marc Okrand]], who developed the [[Klingon language]] for the ''[[Star Trek]]'' films, was hired to devise the Atlantean language for ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''. Guided by the directors' initial concept for it to be a "[[Proto-language|mother-language]]", Okrand employed an [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] word stock with its own [[Grammar|grammatical structure]]. He would change the words if they began to sound too much like an actual, spoken language.<ref name="FilmJournal"/> John Emerson designed the written component, making hundreds of random sketches of individual letters from among which the directors chose the best to represent the Atlantean alphabet.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: Creating Mythology'' at 5:20‚Äì5:47]]</ref><ref>[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 40.]]</ref> The written language was [[boustrophedon]]: designed to be read left-to-right on the first line, then right-to-left on the second, continuing in a zigzag pattern to simulate the flow of water.<ref name="Language"/>
{{quote|text=The Atlantean [A] is a shape developed by John Emerson. It is a miniature map of the city of Atlantis (i.e., the outside of the swirl is the cave, the inside shape is the silhouette of the city, and the dot is the location of the crystal). It's a treasure map.|sign=Kirk Wise, director<ref>[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 82.]]</ref>}}
===Writing=== [[Joss Whedon]] was the first writer to be involved with the film but soon left to work on other Disney projects. According to him, he "had not a shred" in the movie.<ref>[[#Lavery11|Lavery 2011, p. 91.]]</ref> [[Tab Murphy]] completed the screenplay, stating that the time from initially discussing the story to producing a script that satisfied the film crew was "about three to four months".<ref name="Writing">{{cite web|url=http://www.laughingplace.com/News-PID502790-502791.asp|title=An Interview Tab Murphy‚Äî''Atlantis'' Screenwriter|work=Theme Park Adventure Magazine|first=Rick|last=West|date=June 14, 2001|publisher=LaughingPlace.com|accessdate=September 1, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116183959/http://www.laughingplace.com/News-PID502790-502791.asp|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The initial draft was 155 pages, much longer than a typical Disney film script (which usually runs 90 pages). When the first two acts were timed at 120 minutes, the directors cut characters and sequences and focused more on Milo. Murphy said that he created the centuries-old ''Shepherd's Journal'' because he needed a map for the characters to follow throughout their journey.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: History: Creating Mythology'' at 5:58‚Äì6:18]]</ref> A revised version of the script eliminated the trials encountered by the explorers as they navigated the underground caves to Atlantis. This gave the film a faster pace because Atlantis is discovered earlier in the story.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Story and Editorial: Finding the Story'' at 3:58‚Äì7:40]]</ref>
{{quote box|width=30%|align=left|quote=The directors often described the Atlanteans using [[Egypt]] as an example. When [[Napoleon]] wandered into Egypt, the people had lost track of their once-great civilization. They were surrounded by artifacts of their former greatness but somehow unaware of what they meant.|source= ‚ÄîDon Hahn, producer<ref>[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, p. 50.]]</ref>}}
The character of Milo J. Thatch was originally supposed to be a descendant of Edward Teach, otherwise known as [[Blackbeard]] the pirate. The directors later related him to an explorer so he would discover his inner talent for exploration.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Story and Editorial: Finding the Story'' at 2:55‚Äì3:24]]</ref> The character of Moli√®re was originally intended to be "professorial" but Chris Ure, a story artist, changed the concept to that of a "horrible little burrowing creature with a wacky coat and strange headgear with extending eyeballs", said Wise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/reviews/The-Disney-Industrial-Complex-and-Atlantis-The-Lost-Empire|title=The Disney Industrial Complex and ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|last=Messier|first=Max|date=June 12, 2001 |work=FilmCritic.com|publisher=[[AMC Networks|AMC]]|accessdate=September 1, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060310214029/http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/95a45e26914c25ff862562bb006a85f2/dd49aab98adead3a88256a69005c9fe2?OpenDocument|archivedate=March 10, 2006}}</ref><ref>[[#DVD1|''Audio Commentary'' at 17:12‚Äì18.00]]</ref> Don Hahn pointed out that the absence of songs presented a challenge for a team accustomed to animating musicals, as solely action scenes would have to carry the film. Kirk Wise said it gave the team an opportunity for more on-screen character development: "We had more screen time available to do a scene like where Milo and the explorers are camping out and learning about one another's histories. An entire sequence is devoted to having dinner and going to bed. That is not typically something we would have the luxury of doing."<ref name="FilmJournal"/>
Hahn stated that the first animated sequence completed during production was the film's [[prologue]]. The original version featured a [[Viking]] war party using ''The Shepherd's Journal'' to find Atlantis and being swiftly dispatched by the Leviathan. Near the end of production, story supervisor Jon Sanford told the directors that he felt this prologue did not give viewers enough emotional involvement with the Atlanteans. Despite knowing that the Viking prologue was finished and it would cost additional time and money to alter the scene, the directors agreed with Sanford. Trousdale went home and completed the [[storyboards]] later that evening. The opening was replaced by a sequence depicting the destruction of Atlantis, which introduced the film from the perspective of the Atlanteans and Princess Kida.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Story and Editorial: Finding the Story'' at 7:40‚Äì10:25]]</ref> The Viking prologue is included as an extra feature on the [[Atlantis: The Lost Empire#Home media|DVD release]].<ref name="Story2">[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Story and Editorial: Four Deleted Scenes‚Äî"The Viking Prologue"']]</ref>
===Animation=== [[File:Atlantiswidescreencap.gif|thumb|right|alt=A panoramic production still from the film depicting two distant figures standing atop an Atlantean building tower while overlooking a city and a vast lake of water with clouds in the background.|For comparison, the top image (panoramic view of Atlantis) is cropped to Disney's standard aspect ratio (1.66:1); bottom image was seen in the film (2.35:1).]]
At the peak of its production, 350 animators, artists and technicians were working on ''Atlantis''<ref name="Raugust 2004">[[#Raugust04|Raugust 2004, n.p.]]</ref> at all three Disney animation studios: [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Feature Animation]] ([[Burbank, California]]), [[Animation studios owned by The Walt Disney Company#Walt Disney Feature Animation Florida|Disney Feature Animation Florida]] ([[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]]), and [[Animation studios owned by The Walt Disney Company#Disney Animation France|Disney Animation France]] (Paris).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2001-06-15/entertainment/0106140377_1_atlantis-explorers-ordnance-museum|title=The Art of ''Atlantis'' Doesn't Just Imitate Life, It Goes It One Better|first=Roger|last=Moore|date=June 15, 2001|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|accessdate=August 9, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116201606/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2001-06-15/entertainment/0106140377_1_atlantis-explorers-ordnance-museum|archivedate=January 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The film was one of the few Disney animated features produced and shot in [[70 mm film|70mm]] [[anamorphic format]]. The directors felt that a widescreen image was crucial, as a nostalgic reference to old action-adventure films presented in the [[CinemaScope]] format (2.35:1), noting ''[[Raiders of the Lost Ark]]'' as an inspiration.<ref name="Widescreen" /> Because switching to the format would require animation desks and equipment designed for widescreen to be purchased, Disney executives were at first reluctant about the idea.<ref name="FilmJournal"/> The production team found a simple solution by drawing within a smaller frame on the same paper and equipment used for standard [[aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] (1.66:1) Disney-animated films.<ref name="Widescreen">[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: Setting the Scene'' at 1:10‚Äì2:28]]</ref> Layout supervisor Ed Ghertner wrote a guide to the widescreen format for use by the layout artists and mentioned that one advantage of widescreen was that he could keep characters in scenes longer because of additional space to walk within the frame.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: Setting the Scene'' at 2:30‚Äì3:17]]</ref> Wise drew further inspiration for the format from filmmakers [[David Lean]] and [[Akira Kurosawa]].<ref name="FilmJournal"/>
The film's visual style was strongly based upon that of [[Mike Mignola]], the comic book artist behind ''[[Hellboy]]''. Mignola was one of four production designers (along with Matt Codd, Jim Martin, and [[Ricardo Delgado (comics)|Ricardo Delgado]]) hired by the Disney studio for the film. Accordingly, he provided style guides, preliminary character and background designs, and story ideas.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Art Direction: Designing Atlantis'' at 0:50‚Äì4:33]]</ref> "Mignola's graphic, angular style was a key influence on the 'look' of the characters," stated Wise.<ref>[[#Kurtti01|Kurtti 2001, ap. 27.]]</ref> Mignola was surprised when first contacted by the studio to work on ''Atlantis''.<ref name="Mignola" /> His artistic influence on the film would later contribute to a [[cult following]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nextmovie.com/blog/disneys-best-movies-animated-features/|title=Disney's 50 Finest: In Order of Awesome|first=Scott|last=Harris|date=November 29, 2010|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=January 12, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101113344/http://www.nextmovie.com/blog/disneys-best-movies-animated-features/|archivedate=January 1, 2011|quote=On the other hand, the movie does feature a great cast, including Michael J. Fox and James Garner, along with animation by legendary comic book artist and ''Hellboy'' creator Mike Mignola. Because of this last factor, ''Atlantis'' has become a bit of a cult favorite in some circles  ... }}</ref> {{quote|text=I remember watching a rough cut of the film and these characters have these big, square, weird hands. I said to the guy next to me, "Those are cool hands." And he says to me, "Yeah, they're your hands. We had a whole meeting about how to do your hands." It was so weird I couldn't wrap my brain around it.|sign=Mike Mignola<ref name="Mignola">{{cite web|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-07-06/entertainment/17902595_1_comic-book-mike-mignola-dark-horse-comics/2|title=Mike Mignola, ''Hellboy'' Creator, Didn't See Character's Success Coming|first=Stu|last=Horvath|date=July 6, 2008|work=[[New York Daily News]]|accessdate=August 29, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612045542/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-07-06/entertainment/17902595_1_comic-book-mike-mignola-dark-horse-comics/2|archivedate=June 12, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>}}
The final pull-out scene of the movie, immediately before the end-title card, was described by the directors as the most difficult scene in the history of Disney animation. They said that the pullout attempt on their prior film, ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'', "struggled" and "lacked depth"; however, after making advances in the process of [[Multiplane camera|multiplaning]], they tried the technique again in ''Atlantis''. The scene begins with one 16-inch (40.5 cm) piece of paper showing a close-up of Milo and Kida. As the camera pulls away from them to reveal the newly restored Atlantis, it reaches the equivalent of an 18,000-inch (45,720 cm) piece of paper composed of many individual pieces of paper (24 inches [61 cm] or smaller). Each piece was carefully drawn and combined with animated vehicles simultaneously flying across the scene to make the viewer see a complete, integrated image.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Animation Production: Setting the Scene'' at 9:44‚Äì11:26]]</ref>
[[File:Atlantispropsubmarine.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A large model of a mechanical submarine perched atop a flat table mount.|Scale model of ''Ulysses'' submarine by Greg Aronowitz, used by digital animators as reference during production.<ref name="SubModel">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalmediafx.com/Atlantis/atlantisfeature052.html|title=An Inside Look at ''Destination: Atlantis''|first=Joe|last=Tracy|date=June 20, 2001|work=Digital Media FX Magazine|accessdate=September 27, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140117040613/http://www.digitalmediafx.com/Atlantis/atlantisfeature052.html|archivedate=January 17, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>]] At the time of its release, ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' was notable for using more [[computer-generated imagery]] (CGI) than any other Disney traditionally animated feature. To increase productivity, the directors had the digital artists work with the [[traditional animation|traditional animators]] throughout the production. Several important scenes required heavy use of digital animation: the Leviathan, the ''Ulysses'' submarine and sub-pods, the Heart of Atlantis, and the Stone Giants.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Digital Production'' at 0:09‚Äì4:45]]</ref> During production, after Matt Codd and Jim Martin designed the ''Ulysses'' on paper, Greg Aronowitz was hired to build a scale model of the submarine, to be used as a reference for drawing the 3D ''Ulysses''.<ref name="SubModel"/> The final film included 362 digital-effects shots, and computer programs were used to seamlessly join the 2D and 3D artwork.<ref name="USAToday">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/enter/movies/2001-06-07-atlantis.htm|title=Disney Domain Is Under Siege|first=Susan|last=Wloszczyna|date=June 14, 2001|work=USA Today|accessdate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010810032020/http://www.usatoday.com/life/enter/movies/2001-06-07-atlantis.htm|archivedate=August 10, 2001|df=mdy-all}}</ref> One scene that took advantage of this was the "sub-drop" scene, where the 3D ''Ulysses'' was dropped from its docking bay into the water. As the camera floated toward it, a 2D Milo was drawn to appear inside, tracking the camera. The crew noted that it was challenging to keep the audience from noticing the difference between the 2D and 3D drawings when they were merged.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Digital Production'' at 8:15‚Äì9:33]]</ref> The digital production also gave the directors a unique "[[virtual camera]]" for complicated shots within the film. With the ability to operate in the z-plane, this camera moved through a digital [[Wire-frame model|wire-frame set]]; the background and details were later hand-drawn over the wire frames. This was used in the opening flight scene through Atlantis and the submarine chase through the undersea cavern with the Leviathan in pursuit.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Digital Production'' at 5:00‚Äì6:20]]</ref>
===Music and sound=== Since the film would not feature any songs, the directors hired [[James Newton Howard]] to compose the [[Film score|score]]. Approaching it as a live-action film, Howard decided to have different musical themes for the cultures of the surface world and Atlantis. In the case of Atlantis, Howard chose an [[Gamelan|Indonesian orchestral sound]] incorporating chimes, bells, and gongs. The directors told Howard that the film would have a number of key scenes without dialogue; the score would need to convey emotionally what the viewer was seeing on screen.<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Music and Sound'' at 5:00‚Äì8:45]]</ref>
[[Gary Rydstrom]] and his team at [[Skywalker Sound]] were hired for the film's [[Sound recording and reproduction|sound production]].<ref>[[#DVD1|''Audio Commentary'' at 1:50‚Äì2:10]]</ref> Like Howard, Rydstrom employed different sounds for the two cultures. Focusing on the machine and mechanical sounds of the early industrial era for the explorers, he felt that the Atlanteans should have a "more organic" sound utilizing ceramics and pottery. The sound made by the Atlantean flying-fish vehicles posed a particular challenge. Rydstrom revealed that he was sitting at the side of a highway recording one day when a [[Semi-trailer truck|semi-truck]] drove by at high speed. When the recording was sped up on his computer he felt it sounded very organic, and that is what is heard within the film. Rydstrom created the [[harmonic]] chiming of the Heart of Atlantis by rubbing his finger along the edge of a champagne flute, and the sound of sub-pods moving through water with a [[Oral irrigator|water pick]].<ref>[[#DVD2|''Supplemental Features: Music and Sound'' at 0:05‚Äì4:48]]</ref>
==Release== ===Promotion=== ''Atlantis'' was among Disney's first major attempts to utilize [[internet marketing]]. The film was promoted through [[Kellogg Company|Kellogg's]], which created a website with mini-games and a movie-based video game give-away for UPC labels from specially marked packages of ''Atlantis'' breakfast cereal.<ref name="Raugust 2004"/> The film was one of Disney's first marketing attempts through [[mobile network operator]]s, and allowed users to download games based on the film.<ref>{{cite book|last=Steinbock |first=Dan|title=The Mobile Revolution: The Making of Mobile Services Worldwide|year=2007|publisher=[[Kogan Page]]|location=|isbn=978-0-7494-4850-9|pages=158, 304|ref=Steinbock07}}</ref> [[McDonald's]] (which had an exclusive licensing agreement on all Disney releases) promoted the film with [[Happy Meal]] toys, food packaging and in-store decor. The McDonald's advertising campaign involved television, radio, and print advertisements beginning on the film's release date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qsrmagazine.com/news/mcdonalds-dives-disneys-atlantis|title=McDonald's Dives into Disney's ''Atlantis''|date=June 11, 2001|work=QSR Magazine|publisher=Journalistic, Inc.|accessdate=September 1, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012042615/http://www.qsrmagazine.com/news/mcdonalds-dives-disneys-atlantis|archivedate=October 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Frito-Lay]] offered free admission tickets for the film on specially marked snack packages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/news/licensing/cheetos-lovers-get-tickets-atlantis|title=Cheetos Lovers Get Tickets To Atlantis|first=Annick|last=Teninge|publisher=[[Animation World Network]]|date=June 21, 2001|accessdate=April 23, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012063932/http://www.awn.com/news/licensing/cheetos-lovers-get-tickets-atlantis|archivedate=October 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Box office=== Before the film's release, reporters speculated that it would have a difficult run due to competition from [[DreamWorks Animation|DreamWorks]]' ''[[Shrek]]'' (a wholly CGI feature) and ''[[Lara Croft: Tomb Raider]]'' (an action-adventure film from [[Paramount Pictures]]). Regarding the market's shift from traditional animation and competition with CGI films, Kirk Wise said, "Any traditional animator, including myself, can't help but feel a twinge. I think it always comes down to story and character, and one form won't replace the other. Just like photography didn't replace painting. But maybe I'm blind to it."<ref name="USAToday"/> Jeff Jensen of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' noted that CGI films (such as ''Shrek'') were more likely to attract the teenage demographic typically not interested in animation, and called ''Atlantis'' a "marketing and creative gamble".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,256017,00.html|title=High Toon: As the high-tech ''Shrek'' becomes a surprising giant-size success, is the clock ticking for traditionally animated movies?|first=Jeff|last=Jensen|date=June 22, 2001|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=September 2, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224191749/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C256017%2C00.html|archivedate=December 24, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' had its world premiere at Disney's [[El Capitan Theatre]] in Hollywood, California on June 3, 2001<ref>{{cite web|url=http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/010601/laf080a.html|title= World Premiere of Walt Disney Pictures' ATLANTIS: THE LOST EMPIRE ‚Äì Update|date=June 1, 2001|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate= September 22, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010615001509/http://biz.yahoo.com/prnews/010601/laf080a.html|archivedate=June 15, 2001}}</ref> and a limited release in New York City and Los Angeles on June 8; a wider release followed on June 15.<ref name="BOM"/><ref name="USAToday"/> At the premiere, ''Destination: Atlantis'' was on display, featuring behind-the-scenes props from the film and information on the legend of Atlantis with video games, displays, laser tag, and other attractions. The [[Aquarium of the Pacific]] also loaned a variety of fish for display within the attraction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laughingplace.com/News-ID502800.asp|title=''Destination: Atlantis'' at the El Capitan|first=Doobie|last=Moseley|date=June 15, 2001|publisher=LaughingPlace.com|accessdate=September 1, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012035536/http://www.laughingplace.com/News-ID502800.asp|archivedate=October 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> With a budget of $100 million,<ref name="NYTimes"/> the film opened at #2 on its debut weekend, behind ''Lara Croft: Tomb Raider'' earning $20.3 million in 3,011 theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=atlantis.htm|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' Weekend Box-Office|work=Box Office Mojo|publisher=Amazon|accessdate=July 6, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140404121521/http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=weekend&id=atlantis.htm|archivedate=April 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The film's international release began September 20 in Australia and other markets followed suit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=atlantis.htm|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' International Box-Office|work=Box Office Mojo|publisher=Amazon|accessdate=July 6, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140404115408/http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=atlantis.htm|archivedate=April 4, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> During its 25-week theatrical run, ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' grossed over $186 million worldwide ($84 million from the United States and Canada).<ref name="BOM"/> Responding to its disappointing box-office performance, [[Thomas Schumacher]], then-president of Walt Disney Feature Animation, said, "It seemed like a good idea at the time to not do a sweet fairy tale, but we missed."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2001-10-31-animation.htm|title='Toons Get Their Very Own Oscar Category|first=Susan|last=Wloszczyna|date=October 31, 2001|work=USA Today|accessdate=September 2, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527022348/http://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2001-10-31-animation.htm|archivedate=May 27, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Home media {{anchor|DVD|Video|Home release}}=== ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' was released on VHS and DVD January 29, 2002.<ref name="DisneyDVD" /> During the first month of its home release, the film led in VHS sales and was third in VHS and DVD sales combined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.homemediamagazine.com/news/dvd-sales-explode-january-vhs-wanes-2680|title=DVD Sales Explode in January as VHS Wanes|first=Judith|last=McCourt|date=February 28, 2002|work=[[Home Media Magazine]]|accessdate=August 29, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219233337/http://www.homemediamagazine.com/news/dvd-sales-explode-january-vhs-wanes-2680|archivedate=December 19, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Sales and rentals of the VHS and DVD combined would eventually accumulate $157 million in revenue by mid-2003.<ref>[[#Vancheri|Vancheri; Weiskind 2003 p. D‚Äì2]] "Consider what happened with ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''. It earned $84 million at the box office and rebounded with another $157 million in DVD and VHS rentals and sales, according to ''Video Business''."</ref> Both a single-disc DVD edition and a two-disc collector's edition (with bonus features) were released. The single-disc DVD gave the viewer the option of viewing the film either in its original theatrical 2.35:1 aspect ratio or a modified 1.33:1 ratio (utilizing [[pan and scan]]). Bonus features available on the DVD version included audio and visual commentary from the film team, a virtual tour of the CGI models, an Atlantean-language tutorial, an encyclopedia on the myth of Atlantis, and the deleted Viking prologue scene.<ref name="DisneyDVD">{{cite web|url=http://disneydvd.disney.go.com/atlantis-the-lost-empire.html#4102 |title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' |publisher=[[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment]] |accessdate=August 8, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110624124529/http://disneydvd.disney.go.com/atlantis-the-lost-empire.html |archivedate=June 24, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The two-disc collector's edition DVD contained all the single-disc features and a disc with supplemental material detailing all aspects of the film's production. The collector's-edition film could only be viewed in its original theatrical ratio, and also featured an optional [[DTS (sound system)|DTS 5.1]] track. Both DVD versions, however, contained a [[Dolby Digital|Dolby Digital 5.1]] track and were [[THX]] certified.<ref name="DisneyDVD"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/atlantisce.php |title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'': Collector's Edition |first=Michael |last=Rankins |date=May 8, 2002 |publisher=DVD Verdict |accessdate=August 8, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726014412/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/atlantisce.php |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Disney digitally remastered and released ''Atlantis'' on [[Blu-ray]] on June 11, 2013, bundled with its sequel ''[[Atlantis: Milo's Return]]''.<ref name="DisneyBluray">{{cite web|first=John |last=Latchem |url=http://www.homemediamagazine.com/product-news/next-wave-disney-animated-blu-rays-coming-out-june-11-30023 |title=Next Wave of Disney Animated Blu-rays Coming Out June 11 |work=[[Home Media Magazine]] |date=March 28, 2013 |accessdate=March 29, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914174103/http://homemediamagazine.com/product-news/next-wave-disney-animated-blu-rays-coming-out-june-11-30023 |archivedate=September 14, 2013 }}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== The review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 49% of 141 professional critics have given ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' a positive review; the average rating is 5.5/10.<ref name="RotTom">{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/atlantis_the_lost_empire/|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|publisher=[[Fandango (company)|Fandango]]|accessdate=October 18, 2018}}</ref> The site's consensus is: "''Atlantis'' provides a fast-paced spectacle, but stints on such things as character development and a coherent plot".<ref name="RotTom"/> [[Metacritic]] assigned the film a weighted average score of 52 out of 100 based on 29 reviews from mainstream critics; this was considered "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/atlantis-the-lost-empire|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=July 3, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424141313/http://www.metacritic.com/movie/atlantis-the-lost-empire|archivedate=April 24, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[CinemaScore]] polls conducted during the opening weekend revealed the average grade cinema-goers gave ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' was an "A" on an A+-to-F scale.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-trades.com/article.php?id=717 |title=Box Office Analysis: ''Lara Croft'' Raids the Box Office |last=Drysdale |first=Rob |date=June 19, 2001 |publisher=The Trades |accessdate=September 21, 2011 |quote=Not surprisingly ''Atlantis'' scored a very nice set of A's from both men and women under 21 as well as men and women age 21 to 34. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309071540/http://www.the-trades.com/article.php?id=717 |archivedate=March 9, 2013 }}</ref>
While critics had mixed reactions to the film in general, some praised it for its visuals, action-adventure elements, and its attempt to appeal to an older audience. [[Roger Ebert]] gave ''Atlantis'' three-and-half stars out of four. He praised the animation's "clean bright visual look" and the "classic energy of the comic book style", crediting this to the work of Mike Mignola. Ebert gave particular praise to the story and the final battle scene and wrote, "The story of ''Atlantis'' is rousing in an old pulp science fiction sort of way, but the climactic scene transcends the rest, and stands by itself as one of the great animated action sequences."<ref name="Ebert">{{cite web|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20010615/REVIEWS/106150301/1023|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|first=Roger|last=Ebert|date=June 15, 2001|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|accessdate=August 13, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605233148/http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20010615%2FREVIEWS%2F106150301%2F1023|archivedate=June 5, 2011|df=mdy-all}} {{Rating|3.5|4}}</ref> In ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Elvis Mitchell]] gave high praise to the film, calling it "a monumental treat", and stated, "''Atlantis'' is also one of the most eye-catching Disney cartoons since Uncle Walt institutionalized the four-fingered glove."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9404E6DB1F3FF93BA35755C0A9679C8B63|title=''Atlantis: the Lost Empire'' (2001) FILM REVIEW; Under the Sea, Damp Hakuna Matata|first=Elvis|last=Mitchell|date=June 8, 2001|work=The New York Times|accessdate=July 4, 2010}}{{Rating|4|5}}</ref> Internet film critic [[James Berardinelli]] wrote a positive review of the film, giving it three out of four stars. He wrote, "On the whole, ''Atlantis'' offers 90 minutes of solid entertainment, once again proving that while Disney may be clueless when it comes to producing good live-action movies, they are exactly the opposite when it comes to their animated division."<ref>{{cite web|url= http://preview.reelviews.net/movies/a/atlantis.html|title=''Atlantis'' Review|last=Berardinelli|first=James|date=June 2001|publisher=ReelViews.net|accessdate=July 4, 2010}}{{Rating|3|4}}</ref> [[Wesley Morris]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' wrote positively of the film's approach for an older audience: "But just beneath the surface, ''Atlantis'' brims with adult possibility."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/06/15/DD217251.DTL|title=''Atlantis'' Is a Find, Disney Emphasizes Adventure over Cuteness, Romance and Song|first=Wesley|last=Morris|date=June 15, 2001|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=August 13, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110210195313/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2001%2F06%2F15%2FDD217251.DTL|archivedate=February 10, 2011|df=mdy-all}}{{Rating|3|4}}</ref>
Other critics felt that the film was mediocre in regards to its story and characters, and that it failed to deliver as a non-musical to Disney's traditional audience. [[Owen Gleiberman]] of ''Entertainment Weekly'' gave the film a C+ rating, writing that the film had "gee-whiz formulaic character" and was "the essence of craft without dream".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,129378~1~0~atlantislostempire,00.html |title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' |first=Owen |last=Gleiberman |date=June 6, 2001 |work=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=June 26, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527035031/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C129378~1~0~atlantislostempire%2C00.html |archivedate=May 27, 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' said the storyline and characterizations were "old-fashioned" and the film had the retrograde look of a Saturday-morning cartoon, but these deficiencies were offset by its "brisk action" and frantic pace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jun/08/entertainment/ca-7799|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|first=Kenneth|last=Turan|date=July 8, 2001|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202234428/http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jun/08/entertainment/ca-7799|archivedate=December 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}}{{Rating|3.5|5}}</ref> [[Todd McCarthy]] of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' wrote, "Disney pushes into all-talking, no-singing, no-dancing and, in the end, no-fun animated territory."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798244?refcatid=31|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|first=Todd|last=McCarthy|date=June 7, 2001|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|accessdate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108151325/http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798244?refcatid=31|archivedate=November 8, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Stephanie Zacharek of ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]'' wrote of Disney's attempt to make the film for an adult audience, "The big problem with Disney's latest animated feature, ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'', is that it doesn't seem geared to kids at all: It's so adult that it's massively boring."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2001/06/15/atlantis/|title=''Atlantis''‚ÄîDisney's finally made a cartoon for grown-ups. What was wrong with the old ones they made for kids?|date=June 15, 2001|first=Stephanie|last=Zacharek|work=[[Salon.com|Salon]]|accessdate=August 13, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107202846/http://www.salon.com/2001/06/15/atlantis/|archivedate=January 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Rita Kempley of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' panned the film, calling it a "new-fashioned but old-fangled hash" and wrote, "Ironically Disney had hoped to update its image with this mildly diverting adventure, yet the picture hasn't really broken away from the tried-and-true format spoofed in the far superior ''Shrek''."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/entertainment/movies/reviews/atlantiskempley.htm|title='Atlantis': That Sinking Feeling|last=Kempley|first=Rita|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=June 15, 2001|accessdate=March 25, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518120341/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/entertainment/movies/reviews/atlantiskempley.htm|archivedate=May 18, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Themes and interpretations=== Several critics and scholars have noted that ''Atlantis'' plays strongly on themes of [[anti-capitalism]] and [[anti-imperialism]]. M. Keith Booker, academic and author of studies about the implicit messages conveyed by media, views the character of Rourke as being motivated by "capitalist greed" when he pursues "his own financial gain" in spite of the knowledge that "his theft [of the crystal] will lead to the destruction of [Atlantis]".<ref>[[#Booker09|Booker 2009, p. 68.]]</ref> Religion journalist Mark Pinsky, in his exploration of moral and spiritual themes in popular Disney films, says that "it is impossible to read the movie ... any other way" than as "a devastating, unrelenting attack on capitalism and [[American imperialism]]".<ref>[[#Pinsky04|Pinsky 2004, p. 202.]]</ref> Max Messier of [[AMC Networks|FilmCritic.com]] observes, "Disney even manages to lambast the capitalist lifestyle of the adventurers intent on uncovering the lost city. Damn the imperialists!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmcritic.com/reviews/2001/atlantis-the-lost-empire/ |title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' |first=Max |last=Messier |date=June 12, 2001 |work=FilmCritic.com |publisher=[[AMC Networks]] |accessdate=July 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206131254/http://www.filmcritic.com/reviews/2001/atlantis-the-lost-empire/ |archivedate=February 6, 2012 |df=mdy }}</ref> According to Booker, the film also "delivers a rather [[segregationist]] moral" by concluding with the discovery of the Atlanteans kept secret from other surface-dwellers in order to maintain a separation between the two highly divergent cultures.<ref>[[#Booker09|Booker 2009, p. 69.]]</ref> Others saw ''Atlantis'' as an interesting look at [[utopia]]n philosophy of the sort found in classic works of science fiction by [[H. G. Wells]] and Jules Verne.<ref>[[#Montalbano10|Montalbano 2010, p. 183.]]</ref>
When the film was released, some viewers noticed that ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' bore a number of similarities to the 1990‚Äì1991 Japanese anime television program ''[[Nadia: The Secret of Blue Water]]'' and the 1986 film ''[[Castle in the Sky]]'' from [[Studio Ghibli]], particularly in its character design, setting, and story.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2001-05-15|title=Probing the ''Atlantis'' Mystery|first=Lee|last=Zion|date=May 15, 2001|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629004303/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2001-05-15|archivedate=June 29, 2011|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 15, 2012}}</ref> Although Disney never responded formally to claims of [[plagiarism]], co-director Kirk Wise posted on a Disney animation [[Usenet newsgroup|newsgroup]] in May 2001, "Never heard of ''Nadia'' till it was mentioned in this [newsgroup]. Long after we'd finished production, I might add."<ref>[[#Patten04|Patten 2004, p. 187.]]</ref> Both ''Atlantis'' and ''Nadia'' were inspired, in part, by the 1870 Jules Verne novel ''[[Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea]]'', of which Lee Zion (reporting for [[Anime News Network]]) wrote, "There are too many similarities ''not'' connected with ''20,000 Leagues'' for the whole thing to be coincidence."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2001-07-19|title=''Nadia'' vs. ''Atlantis'', Revisited!|first=Lee|last=Zion|date=July 19, 2001|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629004315/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/feature/2001-07-19|archivedate=June 29, 2011|deadurl=no|accessdate=July 15, 2012}}</ref> Critics also saw parallels with the 1994 film ''[[Stargate (film)|Stargate]]''. Milo's characteristics were said to resemble those of [[Daniel Jackson (Stargate)|Daniel Jackson]], the protagonist of ''Stargate'' and its spinoff television series ''[[Stargate SG-1]]''‚Äîwhich coincidentally launched its own spinoff, titled ''[[Stargate Atlantis]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gateworld.net/opinion/columns/gatewatch/review_atlantis_the_lost_e.shtml|title=Review: ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|first=Darren|last=Sumner|publisher=Gateworld|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723134310/http://www.gateworld.net/opinion/columns/gatewatch/review_atlantis_the_lost_e.shtml|archivedate=July 23, 2011|deadurl=yes|accessdate=July 15, 2012|quote=In 1994, Dr. Daniel Jackson decoded an ancient language and unlocked the secrets of the Stargate, sending him and a military unit across the universe to a lost colony of humans. And in 2001, he did it again ‚Äì decoding the ancient Atlantean language to launch a quest to find the lost continent of Atlantis.|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

==Related works== ''Atlantis: the Lost Empire'' was meant to provide a springboard for an animated television series entitled ''Team Atlantis'', which would have presented the further adventures of its characters. However, because of the film's under-performance at the box office, the series was not produced. On May 20, 2003, Disney released a [[direct-to-video]] sequel called ''[[Atlantis: Milo's Return]]'', consisting of three episodes planned for the aborted series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/atlantis2.php |title=Atlantis: Milo's Return |first=Michael |last=Rankins |date=July 31, 2003 |publisher=[[DVD Verdict]] |accessdate=August 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822064947/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/atlantis2.php |archivedate=August 22, 2011 |df= }}</ref> In addition, [[Disneyland]] planned to revive its [[Submarine Voyage]] ride with an ''Atlantis'' theme with elements from the movie and the ride was promoted with a meet-and-greet by the movie's characters. These plans were canceled and the attraction was re-opened in 2007 as the [[Finding Nemo Submarine Voyage]], its theme based on the 2003 [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]]¬∑[[Pixar]] animated film ''[[Finding Nemo]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/la-trw-nemo11jun11,0,841709,full.story|title=Disney Brings Submarine Ride Back from the Depths|first=Kimi|last=Yoshino|date=June 11, 2007|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=July 4, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105202736/http://www.latimes.com/travel/la-trw-nemo11jun11,0,841709,full.story|archivedate=November 5, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Soundtrack=== {{main|Atlantis: The Lost Empire (soundtrack)}} The soundtrack to ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' was released on May 22, 2001. It consists primarily of James Newton Howard's score and includes "[[Where the Dream Takes You]]", written by Howard and [[Diane Warren]] and performed by [[M√Ωa]]. It was also available in a limited edition of 20,000 numbered copies with a unique [[Lenticular printing|3D album cover]] insert depicting the Leviathan from the film. A rare promotional edition (featuring 73 minutes of material, compared to the 53 minutes on standard commercial editions) was intended only for [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] voters but was [[Bootleg recording|bootlegged]] and distributed with fan-created artwork. Concerning the promotional edition, [[Filmtracks.com|Filmtracks]] said, "Outside of about five minutes of superior additional material (including the massive opening, "Atlantis Destroyed"), the complete presentation is mostly redundant. Still, ''Atlantis'' is an accomplished work for its genre."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/atlantis.html|title=Filmtracks: ''Atlantis: The Lost Empire''|date=May 21, 2001|publisher=[[Filmtracks.com]]|accessdate=August 8, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710121111/http://filmtracks.com/titles/atlantis.html|archivedate=July 10, 2014|df=mdy-all}}{{Rating|4|5}}</ref>

''[[Atlantis The Lost Empire: Search for the Journal]]'' (commonly known as ''Atlantis: Search for the Journal'') was developed by [[Zombie Studios]] and published by [[Buena Vista Games]], a subsidiary of [[Disney Interactive]]. It was released on May 1, 2001, for the [[Microsoft Windows]] platform and was a [[first-person shooter]] game, the first of two games based on the film developed by Zombie Studios and released for UPC labels from Kellogg's products for promotion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/04/02/atlantis-the-lost-empire-search-for-the-journal|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire‚ÄîSearch for the Journal'' (PC)|first=Dan|last=Adams|date=April 2, 2001|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=May 15, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219191037/http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/04/02/atlantis-the-lost-empire-search-for-the-journal|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/04/27/cds-n-cereal|title=CDs 'n' Cereal|author=IGN Staff|publisher=IGN|date=April 27, 2001|accessdate=May 15, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219190954/http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/04/27/cds-n-cereal|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> ''[[Atlantis The Lost Empire: Trial by Fire|Atlantis: The Lost Empire‚ÄîTrial by Fire]]'' (commonly known as ''Atlantis: Trial by Fire'') was the second game developed by Zombie Studios and published by Disney Interactive, and was released May 18, 2001, for the Microsoft Windows platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/06/07/atlantis-the-lost-empire-trial-by-fire|title=''Atlantis: The Lost Empire‚ÄîTrial by Fire'' (PC)|first=Dan|last=Adams|date=June 7, 2001|publisher=IGN|accessdate=August 8, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219191140/http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/06/07/atlantis-the-lost-empire-trial-by-fire|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
''Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' is an [[action game]] developed by [[Eurocom]] for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] console which was released June 14, 2001. The player controls Milo, Audrey, Moli√®re, Kida and Vinny as they traverse Atlantis, unlocking its secrets. Some features in the game unlock others (such as a movie) by finding items hidden throughout the game.<ref name=IGNPS>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/07/17/disneys-atlantis-the-lost-empire|title=''Disney's Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' (PlayStation)|first=David|last=Zdyrko|date=July 17, 2001|publisher=IGN|accessdate=May 15, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219190917/http://www.ign.com/articles/2001/07/17/disneys-atlantis-the-lost-empire|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[THQ]] released ''Disney's Atlantis: The Lost Empire'' for the [[Game Boy Advance]] and [[Game Boy Color]]. It is a [[platform game]] in which the player controls Milo and three other characters from the film across 14 levels on a quest to discover Atlantis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gba.gamespy.com/gameboy-advance/disneys-atlantis-the-lost-empire/|title=Atlantis: The Lost Empire|publisher=[[GameSpy]]|accessdate=May 15, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051110100942/http://gba.gamespy.com/gameboy-advance/disneys-atlantis-the-lost-empire/|archivedate=November 10, 2005|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/games/atlantis-the-lost-empire/gbc-16615|title=Atlantis: The Lost Empire - Game Boy Color|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=May 15, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219191124/http://www.ign.com/games/atlantis-the-lost-empire/gbc-16615|archivedate=February 19, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The game was met with average to mixed reviews upon release. [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] gave it a score of 74% and 73 out of 100 for the PlayStation version;<ref name=GRPS/><ref name=MCPS/> 65% for the Game Boy Color version;<ref name=GRGBC/> and 56% and 51 out of 100 for the Game Boy Advance version.<ref name=GRGBA/><ref name=MCGBA/> {{clear}}

[[File:Chopiniana Baku.jpg|thumb|230px|Scene from ''[[Les Sylphides]]'']] In ballet, a '''''ballet blanc''''' ({{IPA-fr|bal…õ bl…ëÃÉ|lang}}, "white ballet") is a scene in which the ballerina and the female ''[[corps de ballet]]'' all wear white dresses or tutus.<ref>Cyril W. Beaumont, ''A French-English Dictionary of Technical Terms Used in Classical Ballet'' (London: Beaumont, 1959), p. 4.</ref> Typical in the [[Romantic ballet|Romantic style]] of ballet from the nineteenth century, ''ballets blancs'' are usually populated by ghosts, dryads, naiads, enchanted maidens, fairies, and other supernatural creatures and spirits.<ref>Ivor Guest, ''The Romantic Ballet in Paris'' (Alton, Hampshire: Dance Books, 2008).</ref>
==History== A precursor of the genre was ''[[Ballet of the Nuns]]'', an episode in act 3 of Giacomo Meyerbeer's opera ''Robert le Diable''. The ghosts of cloistered nuns who, in life, were unfaithful to their vows are summoned from their graves to tempt the hero, Robert, with dancing, gambling, drink, and love making.<ref>"Robert le Diable," in ''The New Kobb√© Opera Book'', 11th ed., edited by the Earl of Harewood and Antony Pettie (New York: Putnam's, 2000), p. 466.</ref> Choreographed by [[Filippo Taglioni]] and first presented in Paris in November 1831, it starred his daughter, [[Marie Taglioni]], as Helena, the abbess of the ruined convent of Saint Rosalia. Costumes in modern productions are usually white dresses with black sashes and headpieces.
The next year, 1832, Marie Taglioni appeared in the title role of ''[[La Sylphide]]'', the story of a wood nymph (a sylphide) who tempts a Scottish farmer, James, to abandon his rural sweetheart and follow her into the woods, in pursuit of ethereal beauty. Dance historians consider this work, as the first fully-fledged ''ballet blanc'', to be the beginning of the Romantic movement in ballet.<ref>Horst Koegler, "Sylphide, La," in ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Ballet'', 2nd ed. (Oxford University Press, 1982).</ref> The name of the genre is derived from the white costume designed by Eug√®ne Lami for Taglioni, which became the recognized dress for dancers of the academic school. The [[ballerina skirt|skirt]] of the Romantic [[tutu (clothing)|tutu]] is either mid-calf or ankle length in design.<ref>A knee-length "bell tutu" was often depicted by [[Edgar Degas]] in his paintings of Parisian ballet dancers of the 1870s. See Richard Kendall, ''Degas Dancers'' (New York: Universe/Vendome, 1996).</ref> Despite the introduction of Romantic elements of otherworldly spirits, the dancing in ''La Sylphide'' was of the purely classical school.<ref>Beaumont, ''A French-English Dictionary'' (1959), p. 4.</ref>
Ghosts, shades, shadows, spirits, and other elemental beings dominated ballet stages for decades after ''La Sylphide''. Famous ''ballets blancs'' were staged in act 2 of ''[[Giselle]]'' (1842), in acts 2 and 4 of ''[[Swan Lake]]'' (1877/1895), in act 2 of ''[[La Bayad√®re]]'' (1877), and in act 1 of ''[[The Nutcracker]]'' (1892). In modern productions, dancers in the lakeside scenes of ''Swan Lake'' and the Kingdom of the Shades scene of ''La Bayad√®re'' sometimes wear short, classical tutus rather than the traditional calf-length or ankle-length ballet dresses, but the visually stunning effect of the ''ballet blanc'' is undiminished. In 1908, [[Michel Fokine]] revived the genre in a ballet set to the music of Fr√©d√©ric Chopin that he entitled ''Chopiniana''. When a revised version was presented in Paris in 1909 by the Ballets Russes of [[Sergei Diaghilev]], it was given the more Romantic title of ''[[Les Sylphides]]''.<ref>George Balanchine and Francis Mason, ''101 Stories of the Great Ballets'' (New York: Doubleday, 1954), ''passim''.</ref> It has remained a popular staple of the ballet repertory for the past century and more.

{{Infobox language |name=Bidiyo |states=[[Chad]] |region=south central |speakers=14,000 |date=1981 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Afro-Asiatic |fam2=[[Chadic languages|Chadic]] |fam3=[[East Chadic languages|East Chadic]] |fam4=[[East Chadic B languages|East Chadic B]] |fam5=[[Dangla languages|Dangla]] (B.1.1) |iso3=bid |glotto=bidi1241 |glottorefname=Bidiyo }}
'''Bidiyo''' (also known as Bidyo, Bidio, 'Bidio, 'Bidiyo, Bidiyo-Waana, Bidiya) is an [[Afro-Asiatic languages|Afro-Asiatic]] language spoken in south central [[Chad]].<ref name=e18/>
== Notes == {{Reflist}}

In: Jean-Pierre Caprile (ed.), √âtudes phonologiques tchadiennes, 87‚Äì112. Paris: Soci√©t√© des Etudes Linguistiques et Anthropologiques de France (SELAF).

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2405:205:130E:9101:668F:2BF2:616E:E888|2405:205:130E:9101:668F:2BF2:616E:E888]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
A '''biological target''' is anything within a living organism to which some other entity (like an endogenous [[ligand (biochemistry)|ligand]] or a [[drug]]) is directed and/or binds, resulting in a change in its behavior or function. Examples of common classes of biological targets are [[protein]]s and [[nucleic acid]]s. The definition is context-dependent, and can refer to the biological target of a [[pharmacological activity|pharmacologically active]] [[drug]] [[Chemical compound|compound]], the receptor target of a [[hormone]] (like [[insulin]]), or some other target of an external stimulus. Biological targets are most commonly proteins such as [[enzyme]]s, [[ion channel]]s, and [[receptor (biochemistry)|receptor]]s.
== Mechanism == The external stimulus (''i.e.'', the drug or ligand) physically binds to ("hits") the biological target.<ref name="pmid2536880">{{cite journal | vauthors = Raffa RB, Porreca F | title = Thermodynamic analysis of the drug-receptor interaction | journal = Life Sciences | volume = 44 | issue = 4 | pages = 245‚Äì58 | year = 1989 | pmid = 2536880 | doi = 10.1016/0024-3205(89)90182-3 }}</ref><ref name="pmid7939660">{{cite journal | vauthors = Moy VT, Florin EL, Gaub HE | title = Intermolecular forces and energies between ligands and receptors | journal = Science | volume = 266 | issue = 5183 | pages = 257‚Äì9 | date = October 1994 | pmid = 7939660 | doi = 10.1126/science.7939660 }}</ref> The interaction between the substance and the target may be: * [[noncovalent bonding|noncovalent]] ‚Äì A relatively weak interaction between the stimulus and the target where no chemical bond is formed between the two interacting partners and hence the interaction is completely reversible. * reversible [[covalent bond|covalent]] ‚Äì A chemical reaction occurs between the stimulus and target in which the stimulus becomes chemically bonded to the target, but the reverse reaction also readily occurs in which the bond can be broken. * irreversible covalent ‚Äì The stimulus is permanently bound to the target through irreversible chemical bond formation.
Depending on the nature of the stimulus, the following can occur:<ref name = "Rang_Dale_2012_Chp_3">{{Cite book |vauthors=Rang HP, Dale MM, Ritter JM, Flower RJ, Henderson G | title = Rang and Dale's Pharmacology | date = 2012 | publisher = Elsevier/Churchill Livingstone | location = Edinburgh; New York | isbn = 0-7020-3471-1 | chapter = Chapter 3: How drugs act: molecular aspects | pages = 20‚Äì48 | chapterurl = }}</ref> * There is no direct change in the biological target, but the binding of the substance prevents other [[endogenous#Biology|endogenous]] substances (such as activating hormones) from binding to the target. Depending on the nature of the target, this effect is referred as [[receptor antagonist|receptor antagonism]], [[enzyme inhibitor|enzyme inhibition]], or [[channel blockers|ion channel blockade]]. * A [[protein structure|conformational]] change in the target is induced by the stimulus which results in a change in target function. This change in function can mimic the effect of the endogenous substance in which case the effect is referred to as [[agonist|receptor agonism]] (or channel or [[enzyme activator|enzyme activation]]) or be the opposite of the endogenous substance which in the case of receptors is referred to as [[inverse agonist|inverse agonism]].
== Drug targets == The term "biological target" is frequently used in [[pharmaceutical]] research to describe the native protein in the body whose activity is modified by a drug resulting in a specific effect, which may be a desirable [[therapeutic effect]] or an unwanted [[adverse effect]]. In this context, the biological target is often referred to as a '''drug target'''. The most common drug targets of currently marketed drugs include:<ref name = "Rang_Dale_2012_Chp_2">{{Cite book |vauthors=Rang HP, Dale MM, Ritter JM, Flower RJ, Henderson G | title = Rang and Dale's Pharmacology | date = 2012 | publisher = Elsevier/Churchill Livingstone | location = Edinburgh; New York | isbn = 0-7020-3471-1 | chapter = Chapter 2: How drugs act: general principles | pages = 6‚Äì19 | chapterurl = http://www.inkling.com/read/rang-dale-pharmacology-ritter-flower-henderson-7th/chapter-2/protein-targets-for-drug-binding }}</ref><ref name="pmid17139284">{{cite journal | vauthors = Overington JP, Al-Lazikani B, Hopkins AL | title = How many drug targets are there? | journal = Nature Reviews. Drug Discovery | volume = 5 | issue = 12 | pages = 993‚Äì6 | date = December 2006 | pmid = 17139284 | doi = 10.1038/nrd2199 }}</ref><ref name="pmid18251718">{{cite journal | vauthors = Landry Y, Gies JP | title = Drugs and their molecular targets: an updated overview | journal = Fundamental & Clinical Pharmacology | volume = 22 | issue = 1 | pages = 1‚Äì18 | date = February 2008 | pmid = 18251718 | doi = 10.1111/j.1472-8206.2007.00548.x }}</ref>
* proteins ** [[G protein-coupled receptor]]s (target of 50% of drugs)<ref name="pmid19513641">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lundstrom K | title = An overview on GPCRs and drug discovery: structure-based drug design and structural biology on GPCRs | journal = Methods in Molecular Biology | volume = 552 | issue = | pages = 51‚Äì66 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19513641 | doi = 10.1007/978-1-60327-317-6_4 }}</ref> ** [[enzyme]]s (especially [[protein kinase]]s, [[protease]]s, [[esterase]]s, and [[phosphatase]]s) ** ion channels *** [[ligand-gated ion channel]]s *** [[voltage-gated ion channel]]s ** [[nuclear receptor|nuclear hormone receptor]]s ** [[Protein#Structural proteins|structural protein]]s such as [[tubulin]] ** [[membrane transport protein]]s * nucleic acids
== Drug target identification ==
Identifying the biological origin of a disease, and the potential targets for intervention, is the first step in the discovery of a medicine using the [[reverse pharmacology]] approach. Potential drug targets are not necessarily disease causing but must by definition be disease modifying.<ref name="Dixon_2009">{{cite journal | vauthors = Dixon SJ, Stockwell BR | title = Identifying druggable disease-modifying gene products | journal = Current Opinion in Chemical Biology | volume = 13 | issue = 5-6 | pages = 549‚Äì55 | date = December 2009 | pmid = 19740696 | pmc = 2787993 | doi = 10.1016/j.cbpa.2009.08.003 }}</ref> An alternative means of identifying new drug targets is [[forward pharmacology]] based on phenotypic screening to identify "orphan" ligands<ref name="Moffat_2017">{{cite journal | vauthors = Moffat JG, Vincent F, Lee JA, Eder J, Prunotto M | title = Opportunities and challenges in phenotypic drug discovery: an industry perspective | journal = Nature Reviews. Drug Discovery | volume = 16 | issue = 8 | pages = 531‚Äì543 | year = 2017 | pmid = 28685762 | doi = 10.1038/nrd.2017.111 | quote = Novelty of target and MoA [Mechanism of Action] is the second major potential advantage of PDD [Phenotypic Drug Discovery]. In addition to identifying novel targets, PDD can contribute to improvements over existing therapies by identifying novel physiology for a known target, exploring ‚Äòundrugged‚Äô targets that belong to well known drug target classes or discovering novel MoAs, including new ways of interfering with difficult-to-drug targets. }}</ref> whose targets are subsequently identified through target deconvolution.<ref name="Lee_2015">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lee H, Lee JW | title = Target identification for biologically active small molecules using chemical biology approaches | journal = Archives of Pharmacal Research | volume = 39 | issue = 9 | pages = 1193‚Äì201 | year = 2016 | pmid = 27387321 | doi = 10.1007/s12272-016-0791-z }}</ref><ref name="Lomenick_2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lomenick B, Olsen RW, Huang J | title = Identification of direct protein targets of small molecules | journal = ACS Chemical Biology | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 34‚Äì46 | date = January 2011 | pmid = 21077692 | pmc = 3031183 | doi = 10.1021/cb100294v }}</ref><ref name="Jung_2015">{{cite journal | vauthors = Jung HJ, Kwon HJ | title = Target deconvolution of bioactive small molecules: the heart of chemical biology and drug discovery | journal = Archives of Pharmacal Research | volume = 38 | issue = 9 | pages = 1627‚Äì41 | year = 2015 | pmid = 26040984 | doi = 10.1007/s12272-015-0618-3 }}</ref>
== Databases ==
Databases containing biological targets information: * [[Therapeutic Targets Database]] (TTD) * [[DrugBank]] * [[BindingDB|Binding DB]]
== Conservation ecology == These biological targets are conserved across species, making pharmaceutical pollution of the environment a danger to species who possess the same targets.<ref name="Gunnarsson_2008">{{cite journal | vauthors = Gunnarsson L, Jauhiainen A, Kristiansson E, Nerman O, Larsson DG | title = Evolutionary conservation of human drug targets in organisms used for environmental risk assessments | journal = Environmental Science & Technology | volume = 42 | issue = 15 | pages = 580713 | date = August 2008 | pmid = 18754513 | doi = 10.1021/es8005173 }}</ref> For example, the synthetic [[estrogen]] in human [[Birth control|contraceptives]], [[17Œ±-ethinylestradiol|17-R-ethinylestradiol]], has been shown to increase the [[Feminization (biology)|feminization]] of fish downstream from sewage treatment plants, thereby unbalancing reproduction and creating an additional [[Evolutionary pressure|selective pressure]] on fish survival.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Larsson DG, Adolfsson-Erici M, Parkkonen J, Pettersson M, Berg AM, Olsson PE, F√∂rlin L | title = Ethinyloestradiol ‚Äî an undesired fish contraceptive? | journal = Aquatic Toxicology | date = April 1999 | volume = 45 | issue = 2-3 | pages = 91‚Äì97 | doi = 10.1016/S0166-445X(98)00112-X }}</ref> Pharmaceuticals are usually found at ng/L to low¬µg/L concentrations in the aquatic environment.<ref name="pmid18200843">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ankley GT, Brooks BW, Huggett DB, Sumpter JP | title = Repeating history: pharmaceuticals in the environment | journal = Environmental Science & Technology | volume = 41 | issue = 24 | pages = 8211‚Äì7 | year = 2007 | pmid = 18200843 | doi = 10.1021/es072658j }}</ref> Adverse effects may occur in non-target species as a consequence of specific drug target interactions.<ref name="pmid17936335">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kostich MS, Lazorchak JM | title = Risks to aquatic organisms posed by human pharmaceutical use | journal = The Science of the Total Environment | volume = 389 | issue = 2-3 | pages = 329‚Äì39 | year = 2008 | pmid = 17936335 | doi = 10.1016/j.scitotenv.2007.09.008 }}</ref> Therefore, [[Evolutionary conservation|evolutionarily well-conserved]] drug targets are likely to be associated with an increased risk for non-targeted pharmacological effects.<ref name="Gunnarsson_2008" />
== See also == * [[Drug discovery]] * [[Environmental impact of pharmaceuticals and personal care products]]
== References == {{Reflist|33em}}
