revision.text:
{{about|a demonym for the Bengalis of [[West Bengal]]||Bong (disambiguation)}}
'''Bong''' is a [[neologism]] that originated in cosmopolitan India in the 1980s as a slightly pejorative [[Exonym and endonym|exonym]] for the educated middle-class Bengalis from the Indian state of [[West Bengal]]. In the 21st century, the term became a self-appellation of pride through the use of satire and self-reflexive irony by the Bengali blogging community, which came to stand for the [[Bengali Hindus|Bengali Hindu people]] as a whole. Bong has been noted as a word of [[Indian English]], used in the Indian newspapers.
== Origin == The usage of Bong as an ethnic quip has been noted in the [[India Today]] in 1989.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/ethnic-quips-become-popular-as-indians-learn-to-make-fun-of-themselves/1/323834.html|title=Indiana jokes|last1=Rajghatta|first1=Chidan|last2=Tripathi|first2=Salil|date=31 August 1989|work=India Today|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> Sociologist Prasanta Roy has noted that the word was used in [[New Delhi]] in the 1990s.<ref name="tt28102007">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraphindia.com/1071028/asp/calcutta/story_8479891.asp|title=The dinner Bong|last1=Banerjee|first1=Malini|last2=Kohli|first2=Diya|date=28 October 2007|work=The Telegraph|publisher=ABP Group|accessdate=4 February 2017|location=Kolkata}}</ref> According to lexicographer Ashoke Mukhopadhyay, Bong is a distortion of the word Bengali that originated among the [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|NRIs]].<ref name="tt28102007"/> Writer [[Nabarun Bhattacharya]] believed that the term originated either in the [[Indian Institutes of Technology|IITs]] or some other pan-Indian educational institutes.<ref name="tt28102007"/> According to a 1999 report in [[The Indian Express]], the gradual extinction of Bengali language and culture and the growing cosmopolitanism in Kolkata have resulted in Bengalis called Bongs by the non-Bengalis.<ref name="ie01071999">{{cite news|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/Storyold/106923/|title=Bongs? No, we're Bengalis from Kolkata|last=Chakrabarti|first=Ashis|date=1 July 1999|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> According to blogger [[Arnab Ray]], the Bengalis were traditionally reluctant to leave [[West Bengal]] for livelihood. However, in the 1980s, the political scenario changed in West Bengal and the Bengalis were forced to leave the state in search of better career options. This led to the development of Bong identity, which is characterized by their emotional attachment towards [[West Bengal]] and at the same time well integrated with the cosmopolitan environment of [[India]] and abroad.<ref name="tt28102007"/>
== Usage == Lexicographer Ashoke Mukhopadhyay believes that the term is slightly pejorative. It has a similar pejorative term as the Hindi term 'Bongali babu' (literally meaning educated Bengali gentleman).<ref name="tt28102007"/> According to sociologist Prasanta Roy, the term conveys hostility, prejudice, political and intellectual dislike.<ref name="tt28102007"/> [[Nabarun Bhattacharya]] believed that the term was used to tease the Bengalis, who themselves harboured chauvinistic attitude towards others.<ref name="tt28102007"/> According to the 1999 report in [[The Indian Express]], the Bengalis disliked the term.<ref name="ie01071999"/>
In the 21st century, the use of Bong has gained currency among the young generation of [[West Bengal]].<ref name="purkayastha">{{cite book|last=Purkayastha|first=Prarthana|title=Indian Modern Dance, Feminism and Transnationalism|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=MMKpBQAAQBAJ|accessdate=4 February 2017|date=29 October 2014|publisher=Springer|isbn= 9781137375179|pages=12‚Äì13}}</ref> Bengali bloggers re-invented their social identity as Bongs.<ref name="sarkar2012">{{cite book|last=Sarkar|first=Sucharita|title=Blogging across Borders ‚Äì Memories, Recipes and Identity in the Diaspora|url=https://www.academia.edu/5108171/Blogging_Across_Borders_Memories_Recipes_and_Identity_in_the_Diaspora|accessdate=4 February 2017|series=Problematics on Ethnicity, Identity and Literature|volume=Pre-Conference Proceeding Volume|year=2012|publisher=SPS Education|isbn=978-81-924140-5-8|pages=851‚Äì858}}</ref> Through satire they have turned the derisive term as a marker of their own ethnic identity.<ref name="sarkar2012"/> Filmmaker [[Anjan Dutt]] believes that Bengalis are okay with calling themselves Bongs.<ref name="tt28102007"/> He used the term Bong instead of Bengali for the title of his 2006 film [[The Bong Connection]] because it was something that can be used with jest just like [[Yankee|Yank]]. According to him terms like Bong or Yank stand for certain quirks and attributes of the person coming from a particular region.<ref name="tt28102007"/> According to [[New Delhi]]-based writer Samit Basu, the people who identify themselves as Bong should fight against the age-old stereotypes of the Bengalis.<ref name="tt28102007"/> Bengalis had become proud to be known as Bong, as it was no longer an offensive parochial label.<ref name="tt28102007"/>
Bong is generally perceived to stand for the global cosmopolitan Bengali.<ref name="tt28102007"/> Blogger [[Arnab Ray]] believes that Bong stands for the globalized Bengali.<ref name="tt28102007"/> According to a Bengali civil servant who blogs as Sadoldbong, Bong stands for the Bengali in exile.<ref name="sarkar2012"/> However, according to [[Anjan Dutt]], there is no cultural or generation gap between the Bong and the Bengali identity.Blogger Sandeepa Mukherjee Datta who blogs as Bong Mom in Bong Mom's Cook Book describes Bong as an identity limited to the Bengali people of West Bengal.<ref name="sarkar2012"/> Durga Puja has been described as a Bong festival.<ref name="tt28102007"/> The prohibition on eating the seasonal [[Ziziphus mauritiana|Indian plum]] before the [[Saraswati Puja]] has been referred to as Bong cultural heritage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.maamatimanush.tv/articles.php?aid=1125|title=Saraswati Puja ‚Äì The Bengali tradition|last=Niyogi|first=Agnivo|date=13 February 2016|work=Maa Mati Manush|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref>
== Derivatives == Bong is listed as a notable word in [[Indian English]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://learningindia.in/references/indian-english-dictionary/|title=Indian English Dictionary and Indianisms|last=Miller|first=Neil A.|work=Learning India|publisher=Madras Media Marketing|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> Contemporary Indian English uses several words that are derived from Bong. Examples include Bongdom (Bengali domination), Bongness (attachment to Bengali culture), Bonglish<ref>{{cite book|editor=Julie Coleman|title=Global English Slang: Methodologies and Perspectives|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=8qbbCgAAQBAJ|date=10 January 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317934769|page=130}}</ref> (pidgin Indian English consisting of [[Bengali language|Bengali]] loanwords), hon-Bong<ref>{{cite news|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrint_TOINEW&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=TOIKM/2011/08/26&ID=Ar01602|title=Why West Bengal is becoming Paschimbanga|last=Suraiya|first=Jug|date=26 August 2011|work=Times of India|publisher=Bennett Coleman & Co.|accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> (abbreviation for honorary Bong, a person who is not a Bong, but can be considered a Bong by virtue of his/her acquaintance and closeness to Bongs and Bong culture).<ref>{{cite book|last=Parhi|first=Asima Ranjan|title=Indian English Through Newspapers|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=-pPLnk1RyHEC|accessdate=4 February 2017|year=2008|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|pages=161‚Äì162}}</ref>
== Stereotypes == The Bengali Hindus as Bongs are often stereotyped especially in [[Bollywood]] and the [[Internet]]. A popular Internet joke goes like this. One Bengali is a poet, two Bengalis are a film society, three Bengalis are a political party and four Bengalis are two political parties!<ref>{{cite book|last=Chaudhuri|first=Diptakirti|title=Kitnay Aadmi Thay|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=CeVeKRFzEt0C|accessdate=1 August 2017|year=2012|publisher=Westland|isbn=9789381626191}}</ref> One common stereotype is that Bongs are invariably fish eaters and often referred to as ''Machher Jhol'', literally meaning fish curry in [[Bengali language|Bengali]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrint_EDU&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=TOIM/2012/06/11&ID=Ar02102|title=Stereotyping could now mean a jail term!|last=D'Costa|first=Melissa|date=11 June 2012|work=The Times of India|publisher=Benett Coleman & Co.|accessdate=1 August 2017|location=Mumbai}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Bongal]] * [[Madrassi]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Neologisms]] [[Category:Ethnic and religious slurs]] [[Category:Reclaimed words]] [[Category:Bengali Hindus]] [[Category:Stereotypes]] [[Category:Indian English]] [[Category:Indian blogs]] [[Category:West Bengal]] [[Category:Regional nicknames]]

{{Orphan|date=August 2018}} {{inline|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox writer | embed = | honorific_prefix = | name = Br√≠d N√≠ Mh√≥r√°in | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1951 <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = Newmarket, County Cork | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = | language = | residence = | nationality = Irish | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | home_town = | period = | genre = <!-- or: | genres = --> | subject = <!-- or: | subjects = --> | movement = | notableworks = poetry <!-- or: | notablework = --> | spouse = <!-- or: | spouses = --> | partner = <!-- or: | partners = --> | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = | module = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.org}} --> | portaldisp = <!-- "on", "yes", "true", etc; or omit --> }} '''Br√≠d N√≠ Mh√≥r√°in''' (born 1951)) is an Irish poet.
==Biography==
N√≠ Mh√≥r√°in was born in [[Newmarket, County Cork]], and raised in west [[County Kerry]]. She taught languages in [[Tralee]] from 1975 to 2001.
==Select works== * ''Ceili√∫radh Cr√©'', [[Coisc√©im]], 1992 * ''F√© Bhrat Bhr√≠de'', An Sagart, 2002 * ''S√≠olta an Iomais'', Cl√≥ Iar-Chonnachta, 2006 * ''An Cos√°n B√°n/The White Path'', Oidhreacht Chorca Dhuibhne 2008
==External links== * https://www.munsterlit.ie/Southword/Contributors/nimhorain_brid.html * https://portraidi.ie/en/brid-ni-mhorain/ * https://www.poetryinternationalweb.net/pi/site/poet/item/22758/30/Brid-Ni-Mhorain * http://www.irishwriters-online.com/ni-mhorain-brid/

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2015}} A '''competent authority''' is any [[person]] or [[organization]] that has the legally delegated or invested authority, capacity, or power to perform a designated function. Similarly, once an authority is delegated to perform a certain act, only the competent authority is entitled to take accounts therefrom and no one else.
'''Borrowing authority '''when the services of a certain [[Class (social)|class]] of individuals are entrusted to one of the authority other than the appointing authority, the former will be the borrowing authority. Borrowing Authority will be authorised to look into the performance of individuals with respect to the task so assigned to them.
'''Borrowing authority''', '''service conduct''' when it appears to the borrowing authority the conduct of the individuals not in accordance with the standard prescribed, it will move in writing to the appointing authority the conduct so observed with the evidence so brought on record for proceedings therein.
'''Appointing authority''', however, is not [[Competence (law)|competent]] to proceed against the individual without such sort of complaint in writing by the authority which delegated the task. Such proceedings if so initiated without any formal complaint will be ''[[coram non judice]]''.
Based on the [[Basel Convention]], it is any national [[Government agency|agency]] responsible under its [[national law]] for the control or regulation of a particular aspect of the transportation of hazardous materials (dangerous goods). The term ''appropriate authority'', as used in the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] (ICAO) Technical Instructions, has the same meaning as competent authority.
[[Category:Legal terminology]]
{{Law-term-stub}}

revision.comment: clean up; edit link; close bracket; using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{essay-like|date=June 2013}} {{Orphan|date=June 2013}} {{Underlinked|date=June 2013}} }} '''Echo complement''' is a syntactic constituent that has either an [[anaphora (linguistics)|anaphoric]] or a [[Metonymy|metonymic]] relation with another constituent in the same sentence.
==Definition== The term seems to have been first used by Guillet and Lecl√®re (1981, pp. 116‚Äì117),<ref>GUILLET, A. AND LECL√àRE, C. 1981. Restructuration du groupe nominal. Langages 63, 99‚Äì125.</ref> in the setting of the operation of ''NP restructuring'', that is, a transformation linking the sentence types: ''N1 of N2 V'' = ''N2 V Prep N1'', e.g. ‚ÄòThe style/architecture of this house is very impressive‚Äô = ‚ÄòThis house is very impressive by/for its style/architecture‚Äô. The concept implies that the notion of ''appropriation'' (Harris 1976:113-115)<ref>HARRIS, Z. S. 1991. A Theory of Language and Information. A Mathematical Approach. Clarendon.</ref> between N1 (v.g. ‚Äòstyle/architecture‚Äô), on one hand, and N2 as argument of V (v.g.) ‚Äòhouse‚Äô and ‚Äò(be) impressive‚Äô, on the other hand, which results from the metonymy between N1 and N2.
Though briefly noted, the term was then used to designate a type of [[preposition]]al complement that renders more ‚Äúprecise‚Äù while recovering, at least partially, the meaning of the utterance (our translation). Even then, the authors considered the notion could be extended to other types of prepositional complements such as: - ''moi-m√™me'' ‚Äòmyself‚Äô in ''J‚Äôai fait √ßa (de/par) moi-m√™me'' ‚ÄòI have done this myself‚Äô, where a redundant reflexive pronoun reinstates the subject NP; or - in ''J‚Äôai un apartment √† moi'' ‚ÄòI have my own apartment/I have an apartment of my own‚Äô, where a redundant/emphatic oblique pronoun (in French) recovers both the subject NP and the possession relation of avoir ‚Äòto have‚Äô. The same term and analysis are more recently retaken by Laporte (2004).<ref>LAPORTE, √â . 2004. Restructuration and the subject of adjectives. Linguisticae Investigationes Supplementa Series, vol. Syntax, Lexis and Lexicon-Grammar. Papers in honour of Maurice Gross. John Benjamins Publishing Co., Amsterdam/Philadelphia, 373‚Äì388.</ref>
In another work (Guillet and Lecl√®re 1992, p. 109),<ref>GUILLET, A. AND LECL√àRE, C. 1992. La structure des phrases simples en fran√ßais: 2-Les constructions transitives locatives. Droz, Paris.</ref> the authors use the term in yet another syntactic setting, v.g. ''mettre du beurre sur'' = ''beurrer'' ‚Äòto put butter over/on = to butter‚Äô, where ''mettre'' 'put' is analysed as a support-verb. This relation, however, could correspond to the ''Fusion'' operation.<ref>GROSS, M. 1981. Les bases empiriques de la notion de pr√©dicat s√©mantique. Langages 63, 7‚Äì52.</ref> Theoretical considerations apart, the relevant observation is that the verbal sentence allows a prepositional complement with the noun whence the verb is derived (V-n). This complements usually zeroed unless it is given a specifying modifier, e.g. ''Max beurre sa tar tine de de beurre (sal√©/de ferme)'' ‚ÄòMax buttered his toast with salted/farm butter‚Äô.
==Use in Portuguese== The term has been adopted for Portuguese by Baptista (2005b, pp. 157‚Äì162),<ref>BAPTISTA, J. 2005b. Sintaxe dos Nomes Predicativos com verbo-suporte SER DE. Funda√ß√£o para a Ci√™ncia e a Tecnologia/Funda√ß√£o Calouste Gulbenkian, Lisboa.</ref> to name apparently facultative human complements introduced by compound preposition ''para com'' ‚Äòtowards‚Äô (lit:‚Äòfor with‚Äô), in support verb constructions, e.g. ''O gesto do Pedro para com o Jo√£o foi de uma grande delicadeza'' = ''O gesto do Pedro foi de uma grande delicadeza para com o Jo√£o'' ‚ÄòPeter‚Äôs gesture towards John was of great delicacy = Peter‚Äôs gesture was of great delicacy towards John‚Äô. Nevertheless, in the same work (Baptista 2005b, p. 165),<ref>BAPTISTA, J. 2005b. Sintaxe dos Nomes Predicativos com verbo-suporte SER DE. Funda√ß√£o para a Ci√™ncia e a Tecnologia/Funda√ß√£o Calouste Gulbenkian, Lisboa.</ref> when referring to the distinction between symmetrical and reciprocal constructions, calls the type of complement here addressed, ''pronominal copy''.
==Other uses== While other authors, namely Guillet and Lecl√®re (1992),<ref>GUILLET, A. AND LECL√àRE, C. 1992. La structure des phrases simples en fran√ßais: 2-Les constructions transitives locatives. Droz, Paris.</ref> Laporte (2004),<ref>LAPORTE, √â . 2004. Restructuration and the subject of adjectives. Linguisticae Investigationes Supplementa Series, vol. Syntax, Lexis and Lexicon-Grammar. Papers in honour of Maurice Gross. John Benjamins Publishing Co., Amsterdam/Philadelphia, 373‚Äì388.</ref> and Baptista (2005a,b),<ref>BAPTISTA, J. 2005a. Constru√ß√µes sim√©tricas: argumentos e complementos. In Estudos de homenagem a M√°rio Vilela, O.Figueiredo, G.Rio-Torto, and F.Silva, Eds.Fac.Letras-U. Porto, pp. 353‚Äì367.</ref><ref>BAPTISTA, J. 2005b. Sintaxe dos Nomes Predicativos com verbo-suporte SER DE. Funda√ß√£o para a Ci√™ncia e a Tecnologia/Funda√ß√£o Calouste Gulbenkian, Lisboa.</ref> may have used the term ''echo complement'' to describe different linguistic phenomena, and apparently have not used it for the specific type of complement here addressed, the term could fit the first definition provided by Guillet and Lecl√®re (1981, pp. 116‚Äì117).<ref>GUILLET, A. AND LECL√àRE, C. 1981. Restructuration du groupe nominal. Langages 63, 99‚Äì125.</ref> Though briefly noted, the term was then used to designate a type of prepositional complement that ‚Äúrenders more ‚Äúprecise‚Äù while recovering, at least partially, the meaning of the utterance‚Äù (our translation).
More recently (Baptista 2005a),<ref>BAPTISTA, J. 2005a. Constru√ß√µes sim√©tricas: argumentos e complementos. In Estudos de homenagem a M√°rio Vilela, O.Figueiredo, G.Rio-Torto, and F.Silva, Eds.Fac.Letras-U. Porto, pp. 353‚Äì367.</ref> the term was used for anaphoric expressions in reciprocal constructions, analysable as the result of the reduction of two coordinated sentences with same predicate but with two constituents in symmetrical position:
''Peter talked with John and John talked with Peter'' ‚Üí ''Peter and John talked with each other''
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Grammar]]

{{unreferenced|date=April 2014}}
A '''financial district''' is the central area in some large cities where [[bank]]s, [[Insurance company|insurance companies]] and other large [[corporation]]s have head offices. Financial districts are often home to [[skyscraper]]s.
==List of financial districts== Notable financial districts of the world include:
===Africa===
==== Algeria ==== *[[Algiers]] (ÿßŸÑÿ¨ÿ≤ÿßÿ¶ÿ±): [[Bab Ezzouar]] (ÿ®ÿßÿ® ÿßŸÑÿ≤Ÿàÿßÿ±)
==== Kenya ====
* [[Nairobi]]: [[Upper Hill, Nairobi|Upper Hill]]
====Mauritius==== *[[Port Louis]]: [[Place D'armes]]
==== Morocco ==== *[[Casablanca]] (ÿßŸÑÿØÿßÿ± ÿßŸÑÿ®Ÿäÿ∂ÿßÿ°): [[Anfa (arrondissement)|Anfa]] (ÿ£ŸÜŸÅÿß), [[Ma√¢rif]] (ÿßŸÑŸÖÿπÿßÿ±ŸäŸÅ), [[Sidi Belyout]] (ÿ≥ŸäÿØŸä ÿ®ŸÑŸäŸàÿ∑), [[Sidi Ma√¢rouf]] (ÿ≥ŸäÿØŸä ŸÖÿπÿ±ŸàŸÅ), [[Bouskoura]] (ÿ®Ÿà ÿ≥ŸÉŸàÿ±ÿ©)
====South Africa==== *[[Johannesburg]]: [[Sandton]]
===Americas===
====Argentina==== *[[Buenos Aires]]: [[Buenos Aires CBD|Microcentro]] and [[Diagonal Norte]]
====Brazil==== *[[Rio de Janeiro]]: [[Centro, Rio de Janeiro|Centro]] *[[S√£o Paulo]]: [[Alphaville, S√£o Paulo|Alphaville]], [[Brooklin Novo|Brooklin]], [[Central Zone of S√£o Paulo|Central Zone]], [[Paulista Avenue]], and [[Vila Ol√≠mpia]]
====Canada==== *[[Montreal]]: [[Saint Jacques Street]] *[[Toronto]]: [[Financial District, Toronto|Financial District]] ([[Bay Street]], a [[metonym]] for the district) *[[Vancouver]]: [[Financial District, Vancouver|Financial District]]
====Chile==== *[[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]]: [[Sanhattan]]
====Mexico==== *[[Guadalajara]]: [[Puerta de Hierro, Guadalajara|Puerta de Hierro]] *[[Mexico City]]: [[Polanco]], [[Paseo de la Reforma]], and [[Santa Fe (Mexico City)|Santa Fe]] *[[Monterrey]]: [[Valle Oriente]]
====Paraguay==== *[[Asuncion]]: Aviadores del Chaco Avenue
====Peru==== *[[Lima]]: [[San Isidro District, Lima|San Isidro]], [[Miraflores District, Lima|Miraflores]] and [[Historic Centre of Lima|Historic Centre]] *[[Arequipa]]: [[Cayma District|Cayma]]
====United States==== *[[Atlanta]]: [[Buckhead]] *[[Boston]]: [[Financial District, Boston|Financial District]] *[[Chicago]]: [[LaSalle Street]] *[[Detroit]]: [[Detroit Financial District|Financial District]] *[[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]]: [[Laura Street]] *[[Los Angeles]]: [[Financial District, Los Angeles|Financial District]] *[[Miami]]: [[Brickell]] *[[New York City]]: [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]], [[Midtown Manhattan]] *[[Philadelphia]]: [[Penn Center, Philadelphia|Penn Center]] *[[San Francisco]]: [[Financial District (San Francisco)|Financial District]] *[[Seattle]]: [[Downtown Seattle|Financial District]] *[[Des Moines]]: [[Downtown Des Moines|Financial District]]
===Oceania===
====Australia==== *[[Sydney]]: [[Martin Place]] *[[Melbourne]]: [[Collins Street, Melbourne|Collins Street]] *[[Brisbane]]: [[Creek Street, Brisbane|Creek Street]] *[[Perth]]: [[St Georges Terrace]]
====New Zealand==== *[[Auckland]]: [[Auckland CBD|Central Business District (CBD)]]
===Asia===
====Bangladesh==== *[[Chittagong]]: [[Agrabad]] *[[Dhaka]]: [[Motijheel]] *[[Dhaka]]: [[Gulshan Thana]] *[[Dhaka]]: [[Kawran Bazar]]
====China==== *[[Beijing]]: [[Beijing Financial Street]] *[[Hong Kong]]: [[Central, Hong Kong|Central]] and [[Sheung Wan]] *[[Shanghai]]: [[Lujiazui]] in [[Pudong]] *[[Shenzhen]]: [[Futian District]] *[[Guangzhou]]: [[Zhujiang New Town]]
====India==== *[[Mumbai]]: [[Dalal Street]], [[Bandra-Kurla Complex]] *[[Hyderabad]]: [[Nanakramguda]]
====Indonesia==== *[[Jakarta]]: [[Jalan H.R. Rasuna Said]], [[Jalan Jenderal Gatot Subroto]], [[Jalan Jenderal Sudirman]], and [[Jalan M.H. Thamrin]] *[[Surabaya]]: [[Tunjungan]] *[[Yogyakarta]]: [[Malioboro]]
====Israel==== *[[Tel Aviv]]: [[Rothschild Boulevard]]
====Japan==== *[[Nagoya]]: [[Naka-ku, Nagoya|Naka-ku]] *[[Osaka]]: [[Ch≈´≈ç-ku, Osaka|Ch≈´≈ç-ku]] *[[Tokyo]]: [[Marunouchi]], [[Nihonbashi]], and [[Otemachi]]
====Lebanon==== *[[Beirut]]: [[Beirut Central District|Central District]]
====Malaysia==== *[[George Town, Penang|George Town]]: [[Beach Street, George Town|Beach Street]] *[[Kuala Lumpur]]: [[Kuala Lumpur City Centre]]

====Philippines==== *[[Makati]]: [[Ayala Center]] *[[Mandaluyong]]: [[Ortigas Center]] *[[Manila]]: [[Binondo]]

====South Korea==== *[[Seoul]]: [[Yeouido]] and [[Teheranno]]
====Taiwan==== *[[Taipei]]: [[Xinyi District, Taipei|Xinyi]], [[Zhongzheng District|Taipei Station]] and [[Eastern District of Taipei|East End]]
====Thailand==== *[[Bangkok]]: [[Sathorn]] and [[Silom]]
====Turkey==== *[[Istanbul]]: [[Levent]], [[Ata≈üehir]] and [[Maslak]]
====Vietnam==== *[[Ho Chi Minh City]]: [[District 1, Ho Chi Minh City|District 1]]
===Europe===
====Belgium==== *[[Brussels]]: [[Northern Quarter (Brussels)|Northern Quarter]]
====France==== *[[Lyon]]: [[La Part-Dieu]] *[[Marseille]]: [[Eurom√©diterran√©e]] *[[Paris]]: [[La D√©fense]]
====Germany==== *[[Berlin]]: [[Potsdamer Platz]] *[[Frankfurt]]: [[Bankenviertel]]
====Greece==== *[[Athens]]: [[Sofokleous Street]]
====Italy==== * [[Milan]]: [[Centro Direzionale di Milano]] and [[Porta Nuova (Milan)|Porta Nuova]] * [[Naples]]: [[Centro Direzionale (Naples)|Centro Direzionale di Napoli]] * [[Rome]]: [[EUR, Rome|EUR]]
====Netherlands==== *[[Amsterdam]]: [[Zuidas]] and [[Damrak]]
====Russia==== *[[Moscow]]: [[Moscow International Business Centre]], [[Kitay-gorod]], and [[Tverskoy District]]
====Spain==== *[[Barcelona]]: [[22@]] and [[Granvia l'Hospitalet]] *[[Madrid]]: [[AZCA]] and [[Cuatro Torres Business Area|CTBA]]
====Switzerland==== *[[Zurich]]: [[Paradeplatz]]
====United Kingdom==== *[[London]]: [[City of London]] and [[Canary Wharf]] *[[Leeds]]: [[Leeds city centre#Financial Quarter|Financial Quarter]]
==See also== *[[Central business district]] *[[Financial center]]

[[Polish Academy of Literature]] (1936)"Lista odznaczonych z≈Çotym i serbrnym 'wawrzynem akademickim'" (List of the Recipients of the Golden and Silver Laurels of the Academy [of Literature]), ''[[Ilustrowany Kurier Codzienny|Ilustrowany Kuryer Codzienny]]'' ([[Krak√≥w]]), vol. 27, No. 313, 10 November 1936, p. 4. }} '''Franciszka Arnsztajnowa''' ({{IPAc-pl|f|r|a|≈Ñ|'|ƒá|i|sz|k|a|-|a|r|n|sz|t|a|j|'|n|o|w|a}}; in full: ''Franciszka Hanna Arnsztajnowa''; 19 February 1865 ‚Äì August 1942) was a Polish poet, playwright, and translator of Jewish descent.So ''S≈Çownik biograficzny miasta Lublina'' (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]). Much of her creative ''oeuvre'' falls within the [[Young Poland]] period, stylistically encompassing the twilight of [[neo-romanticism]]. She is called "the legend of [[Lublin]]".Aleksander B. Skotnicki, ''et al.'', ''Jewish Society in Poland: Customs and Participation in the Fight for Independence: Many Faces of Cracovian Jewry'', tr. J. Niedbal & K. Baran, [[Krak√≥w]], Wydawnictwo, 2009, p. 109. {{ISBN|9788361060765}}, {{ISBN|8361060766}}. ==Family== Franciszka Arnsztajnowa was the daughter of the [[Lublin]]-based novelist [[Malwina Meyerson]] (real name, Ma≈Çka Meyerson, ''n√©e'' Horowicz (Horowitz); 1839{{ndash}}1921), a Lublin native, and Bernard (Berek, or Ber) Meyerson (b. 1837), a native of [[Tykocin]], an international trader and a major Lublin financier. Her brother was the French philosopher, [[√âmile Meyerson]], based in Paris. She attended high school for girls in Lublin, and went to Germany for higher studies in biology, travelling extensively in Europe. On 7 January 1885 she married [[Marek Arnsztein]] (alternative spellings: Arnsztejn, Arnsztajn, Arnstein; 1855{{ndash}}1930), a physician educated in [[Warsaw]], Vienna, Berlin, and Paris, and a political and social activist, a native of [[Kazimierz Dolny]] based in Lublin from 1884. They had a daughter, Stefanja Arnsztajn√≥wna (''c.''1890{{ndash}}1942; married name Mieczys≈Çawska), and a son, Jan Arnsztajn (1897{{ndash}}1934), much beloved of Arnsztajnowa and whose death from [[tuberculosis]] left her devastated. ==Life and work== As a poet Arnsztajnowa debuted at the age of 23 with the poem "Na okrƒôcie" (On Board a Ship) published in the newspaper ''[[Kuryer Codzienny]]'' of 1 October 1888. She issued her first collection of poetry in book form in 1895 under the title ''Poezye'', a volume which she dedicated to her mother, the novelist Malwina Meyerson.F. Arnsztajnowa, ''Poezye'', [[Warsaw]], Gebethner i Wolff, 1895. (88 pp.) The book is divided into six distinct sections under such headings as "Sonety" (Sonnets), "Melodye" (Melodies), "Historye" (Histories), and "Z g√≥r Tyrolu" (From the Mountains of [[South Tyrol|Tyrol]]). The opening poem, untitled but beginning with the words "O nie p≈Çacz..." (Weep thou not...; p. 7), sets the tone for the entire collection as she tries, with uncommon tenderness and filial piety, to soothe her mother's pain at having her own songs dispersed by the winds of time to the farthermost recesses of the soul: the implication is that the poems in this collection will become her mother's own, which the daughter will now sing for her, the lute in hand, sitting at her feet. (In the very last poem of the collection the poet again addresses her mother directly, "O mother, why give me a heart so | Tender...")F. Arnsztajnowa, [untitled poem]; in ''[[id.]]'', ''Poezye'', [[Warsaw]], Gebethner i Wolff, 1895, p. 88. The chief characteristic of the collection, thematically speaking, was however the preoccupation and love she evinced for the people living close to the land, their ordinary lives and [[Folklore|folkloric customs]]. At the same time she delicately touched upon the social questions of the day employing language in the balladic-melancholic key.Feliks Araszkiewicz (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]), p. 115. The volume will instantly establish Arnsztajnowa as a major voice in Polish poetry among those exploring the nation's [[Folk culture|folk themes]].Cf. [[Stanis≈Çaw Zdziarski]], ''Pierwiastek ludowy w poezji polskiej XIX wieku: studja por√≥wnawczo-literackie'', [[Warsaw]], E. Wende, 1901. Her next collection appeared in 1899 under the title ''Poezye: serya druga'' ("Verses: Second Series"; 2nd ed., 1911).F. Arnsztajnowa, ''Poezye: serya druga'', [[Krak√≥w]], G. Gebethner i Sp√≥≈Çka, 1899. The latter volume contains the poem "Z nocy bezsennych" (Out of the Sleepless Nights) dedicated to her husband, Marek Arnsztein, as well as the memorable "Wspomnienie Meranu" (A Remembrance of [[Merano]]) that evokes her travels in the [[Trentino-Alto Adige]] region of Italy, and which begins:
''Meran‚Ä¶ pamiƒôtam‚Ä¶ nieraz dzi≈õ w zimy rozgwarze, ''Mro≈∫nem tchnieniem owiana, nagle zamknƒô oczy, ''I o b≈Çogos≈Çawionej dolinie zamarzƒô.''F. Arnsztajnowa, ‚ÄúWspomnienie Meranu‚Äù (A Remembrance of [[Merano]]; lines 1{{ndash}}3); in ''[[id.]]'', ''Poezye: serya druga'', 2nd ed., [[Warsaw]], Gebethner i Wolff, 1911, p. 90. __________________________________ Meran‚Ä¶ I recall‚Ä¶ as nowadays oft by winter's clamorous decree Frosty gusts me shroud, I soon close my eyes asudden And slip down the blessed valley into reverie.
[[Wac≈Çaw Gralewski]] (1900{{ndash}}1972), a poet and prominent Lublin ''[[litt√©rateur]]'', cites a report (which he qualifies as uncorroborated) that Arnsztajnowa was supposed to undergo a (successful) therapy for [[tuberculosis]] at Merano, an option open only to the very rich.[[Wac≈Çaw Gralewski]], ''Stalowa tƒôcza: wspomnienia o [[J√≥zef Czechowicz|J√≥zefie Czechowiczu]]'', [[Warsaw]], Pa≈Ñstwowy Instytut Wydawniczy, 1968, p. 60. ===The First World War=== {| class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 1em; font-size: 97%; background:#c6dbf7; width:29em; max-width: 55%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | O Dniu Jutrzejszy! KielniƒÖ i mieczem stawiaƒá wƒôg≈Çy domu. |- | style="text-align: right; font-size: 85%;" | '''"O Dniu Jutrzejszy" (O, Thou Day of the Morrow!; 1914)'''
{{mdash}} from ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' (1924)F. Arnsztajnowa, "O Dniu Jutrzejszy" (O, Thou Day of the Morrow!); in ''[[id.]]'', ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'', [[Lublin]], Sp√≥≈Çdzielnia Wydawawnicza Plac√≥wka Lubelska, 1924, p. 13. Exceptionally, in contravention of Polish typographic conventions, all words of the poem's title are capitalized in the original to indicate [[pathos]]. |} During the [[First World War]] Arnsztajnowa (''[[nom de guerre]]'' Ara) participated in armed struggle for the independence of Poland as a member of the secret [[Polish Military Organisation]] in Lublin (her town house in the Old Town of Lublin served as a secret archive of the [[Polish Military Organisation|POW]] and a hub for other organizations, such as the [[Union of Armed Struggle]] and the [[Scouting and Guiding in Poland|clandestine Polish boy scout movement]]; the expansive basement served as an arsenal). Some of the patriotic feelings and motivations that actuated her participation in the freedom struggle will later find an echo in her collection of poetry entitled ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' ("The Archangel of the Morrow"), comprising verses written during the war, which she will publish in 1924 dedicating it to the alumni of the Lublin schools who had fallen in that struggle.F. Arnsztajnowa, ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'', [[Lublin]], Sp√≥≈Çdzielnia Wydawawnicza Plac√≥wka Lubelska, 1924. (31 pp.) With two compositions included in the volume Arnsztajnowa paid tribute to the luminaries of Polish literature, [[Maria Konopnicka|Marja Konopnicka]] and [[Boles≈Çaw Prus]], both recently deceased then. However, it is to [[Stefan ≈ªeromski]] (after ''his'' death in 1925) that Arnsztajnowa will in the latter part of her life acknowledge her indebtedness for the general character of her ''oeuvre'' and the direction she followed in creating it.Feliks Araszkiewicz (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]), p. 119. ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' contains verses of great strength and incisiveness, unparalleled in her prior work, the composition "O Dniu Jutrzejszy" (O, Thou Day of the Morrow!), written in 1914, belonging to the most beautiful among them in the opinion of the [[history of literature|historian]] of [[Polish literature|literature]], [[Feliks Araszkiewicz]].So Feliks Araszkiewicz (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]), p. 117. The poem speaks of the brethren's (comrades-in-arms') blood shed in the struggle, whose rising vapours conceal the mystery of tomorrow (the day is [[personification|personified]] in the poem, addressed as "you", and conceived of as a day of reckoning, indeed, as a [[metonymy]] for [[retributive justice]] itself): the mystery of tomorrow will be revealed once we tear down your deadly veil to look you directly in the face, without the sort of fear that makes the victim bow his head before the executioner: for tomorrow we know full well will be the day of payback for today. (The poem, heavily dependent on stylized linguistics and medieval vocabulary (e.g., ''gz≈Ço'', line 3, a medieval term for a kind of female garment, here used figuratively in the sense of "veil"), does not lend itself easily to verse translation but is reproduced in the original to the left.) Thus the archangel of the title of the entire collection, ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' (‚ÄúThe Archangel of the Morrow‚Äù), can easily be construed as the [[Destroying angel (Bible)|avenging angel]]. Another composition belonging to this period is the poem entitled "Powr√≥t" (The Return) published in a literary journal in April 1916. Comprising five ''[[ottava rima]]'' stanzas, the 40-line poem brought her the Silver Laurel of the [[Polish Academy of Literature]], a (now historical) body awarding the most prestigious literary honours of the land at the time.F. Arnsztajnowa, "Powr√≥t", ''Sprawa Polska'' ([[Lublin]]), No. 13, 18 April 1916, p. 11. ===The interwar period=== During the [[Interbellum]] Arnsztajnowa collaborated with the newspapers and [[literary magazine]]s ''[[Dziennik Lubelski]]'', ''[[Kamena (magazine)|Kamena]]'', and ''[[Kurjer Lubelski]]''; she was the editor-in-chief of the literary supplement ''Dodatek Literacki'' to the newspaper ''[[Ziemia Lubelska]]''. At the same time she was the moving spirit of the literary life of the city of Lublin, a fact recognized by outside observers,Cf. [[Jan Szczawiej]], "≈ªycie literackie w Lubelszczy≈∫nie", ''[[Ilustrowany Kurier Codzienny|Ilustrowany Kuryer Codzienny]]'' ([[Krak√≥w]]), vol. 25, No. 28, 28 January 1934, p. 3. co-founding in 1932, together with the poet [[J√≥zef Czechowicz]], the Lublin section of the writers' union, the ZwiƒÖzek Literat√≥w (see [[Polish Writers' Union]]), of which she served as the president. To this period, in addition to the aforementioned collection ''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' (1924), belong also her volumes of poetry entitled ''Odloty'' ("Flying Away"; 1932),F. Arnsztajnowa, ''Odloty'', [[Lublin]], ZwiƒÖzek Literat√≥w w Lublinie, 1932. a compilation of verses published in [[literary magazine|literary journals]] between 1902 and 1926, and the collection produced jointly with J√≥zef Czechowicz, ''Stare kamienie'' ("Old Stones"; 1934) which was at once a tribute to her beloved Lublin, a city in which she continued to reside until 1934, epitomized in the poem "Tobie ≈õpiewam, Lublinie" (To You do I Sing, O Lublin!), and a form of a literary farewell.Franciszka Arnsztajnowa & [[J√≥zef Czechowicz]], ''Stare kamienie: [poezye]'', [[Lublin]], [n.p.], 1934. Contemporary critics observed that the unspecified nature of the collaboration between the two famous poets gave the publication an anonymous tinge,K. W. Zawodzi≈Ñski, "Liryka" (Lyric Poetry); in ''Rocznik Literacki za rok 1934'', ed. Z. Szmydtowa, [[Warsaw]], Instytut Literacki, 1935, p. 53. and although subsequent scholarship clearly differentiated between the pieces written by Arnsztajnowa and those written by Czechowicz mistakes of attribution did occur in succeeding years and decades.[[Tadeusz K≈Çak]], ''Miasto poet√≥w: poezja lubelska, 1918{{ndash}}1939'', [[Tarn√≥w]], The Author; [[Lublin]], Wojew√≥dzki Dom Kultury, 2001. {{ISBN|8391501825}}. ''Odloty'' represents a continuation of the [[Modernism|modernist]] esthetics that dominated the first phase of Arnsztajnowa's literary life, as evidenced in the imagery employed and in the method of shaping of the lyrical persona, as well as in the return of the [[Fairy tale|fairy-tale]] [[Motif (narrative)|motifs]] favoured by the [[Young Poland]] poets, such as lakes, mirrors, and shadows. Although on occasion she adopts a new cadence closer to the spirit of the [[Skamander]] circle then gaining an ascendancy over [[Polish poetry|Polish poetics]], such diversions are rare. The title poem, "Odloty" (Flying Away), first printed in a literary magazine in 1905, is a mystical allegory on the inevitability of the departure, of parting despite the ties thereby shattered.F. Arnsztajnowa, "Odloty", ''Ateneum'' ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 3, No. 9, September 1905, p. 165. Arnsztajnowa was co-founder of the historically important [[Krak√≥w]] periodical ''[[≈ªycie]]'' famously associated with the artistic avant-garde and with the person of [[Stanis≈Çaw Przybyszewski]], for which she wrote a programmatic poem, and had close ties to the [[literary magazine]] ''[[Kamena (magazine)|Kamena]]'' (see [[:pl:Kamena (czasopismo)|''Kamena'']]), founded and edited by [[Kazimierz Andrzej Jaworski|K. A. Jaworski]]: the journal began publication in 1933 with a poem by Arnsztajnowa, "Na Olejnej" (In Olejna Street), on the first page of the first issue.Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, "Na Olejnej (z cyklu ''Stare kamienie'')" (In Olejna Street {{mdash}} from the ''Stare kamienie'' Cycle), ''Kamena'' ([[Che≈Çm|Che≈Çm Lubelski]]), vol. 1, No. 1, September 1933, p. 1. [http://biblioteka.teatrnn.pl/dlibra/dlibra/doccontent?id=24463 See online.] Right-wing critics (such as [[Julian Babi≈Ñski|Juljan Babi≈Ñski]], 1900{{ndash}}1943) accused Arnsztajnowa of left-wing bias against the ''[[szlachta]]'', in favour of the common people.[[Julian Babi≈Ñski|Juljan Babi≈Ñski]], "Na marginesie", ''Tƒôcza: ilustrowany miesiƒôcznik'' ([[Pozna≈Ñ]]), vol. 11, No. 5, May 1937, p. 85. ====Prose==== Arnsztajnowa's innumerable writings in prose, strewn across innumerable journals and magazines, frequently published under pseudonyms that even Arnsztajnowa could not keep track of during her lifetime, present an impossible task for a compiler wishing to present a reasonably comprehensive picture of her bibliography {{mdash}} as observed by the historian of literature and her contemporary, [[#Bibliography|Feliks Araszkiewicz]] (1895{{ndash}}1966).Feliks Araszkiewicz (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]), p. 114. Among the pen-names she is known to have used are '''J. G√≥recka''', and '''Stefan Orlik'''. ====Dramatic works==== Arnsztajnowa's dramatic works remain largely confined to manuscript, including her award-winning play ''Na wy≈ºynach (Krystyna)'' ("On the Heights: Christina") which was staged to great acclaim in [[Lviv|Lvov]] in 1899. Her other plays which were seen on the stages of [[Krak√≥w]] and [[≈Å√≥d≈∫]], in addition to those of Lublin and Lvov, but which remain unpublished, are (with dates of theatre production) ''Na kuracji'' ("A Stay at a Spa"; 1894), ''Perkun'' ("[[Perk≈´nas]]"; 1896), and ''W stojƒÖcej wodzie'' ("In the Stagnant Water"; 1901). Only two one-act plays have been published (in [[literary magazine|literary journals]]), ''Widmo: Ballada w I akcie'' ("The Spectre: A [[Ballad]] in One Act"; published in ''[[Ateneum (magazine)|Ateneum]]'' in 1905, a dialogue between two characters identified only as male and female),F. Arnsztajnowa, "Widmo: Ballada w I akcie", ''[[Ateneum (magazine)|Ateneum]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), Year III, vol. 1, Nos. 1{{ndash}}3, January{{ndash}}March 1905, pp. 104{{ndash}}109. and ''Luxoniolo'' (published in the ''[[Kurjer Lubelski]]'' in 1911).Julian Krzy≈ºanowski, ''Neoromantyzm polski, 1890{{ndash}}1918'', 3rd ed., ed. T. Brzozowska-Komorowska & M. Bokszczanin, [[Wroc≈Çaw]], Zak≈Çad Narodowy im. Ossoli≈Ñskich, 1980, p. 347. {{ISBN|8304003902}}. The play ''C√≥rka'' ("The Daughter") has never been staged or published. ====Translatorial work and other avocations==== Arnsztajnowa participated in the [[Women's suffrage|women's suffrage movement]], supporting with readings from her poems the meetings and events of organizations involved in the movement, including the [[ZwiƒÖzek R√≥wnouprawnienia Kobiet Polskich]] (Union for the Equal Rights of Polish Women) founded in 1907 by [[Paulina Kuczalska-Reinschmit]] (1859{{ndash}}1921)."Z ≈ºycia prowincji" (From the Life of the Provinces), ''[[G≈Ços Warszawski]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 2, No. 92, 2 April 1909, p. 2. (See also [[:pl:Paulina Kuczalska-Reinschmit|Paulina Kuczalska-Reinschmit]].) In 1912 Arnsztajnowa participated in a feminist exhibition mounted by Polish women writers in [[Prague]].''Pam√°tn√≠k v√Ωstavy pr√°ce ≈æeny polsk√© v Praze 1912'', comp., ed. & tr. Pavla Maternov√°, [[Prague]], √öst≈ôedn√≠ spolek ƒçesk√Ωch ≈æen, 1912. Cf. Helena Rzepecka, "Zbiorowy g≈Ços dora≈∫ny" (The Collective Voice of the Moment), ''Literatura i Sztuka'' ([[Pozna≈Ñ]]), vol. 4, No. 36, 8 September 1912, pp. 563{{ndash}}567. Apart from her own extensive poetic ''oeuvre'', Arnsztajnowa produced several translations from English literature. Her translation of [[Douglas Jerrold]]'s famous ''[[:s:Mrs. Caudle's curtain lectures|Mrs Caudle's Curtain Lectures]]'', published in 1923 as ''Nauki ma≈Ç≈ºe≈Ñskie pani Caudle'', was issued with the name of the translator concealed under a pseudonym (Stefan Orlik) as she did not wish to lend the [[Reputation|prestige]] that her name enjoyed in the domain of poetry to what she considered to be her [[avocation]]. Her translations of [[H. G. Wells]]'s ''[[The Sea Lady|The Sea Lady: A Tissue of Moonshine]]'' (published as ''Syrena: ksiƒô≈ºycowa opowie≈õƒá'' in 1927), and of [[W. Somerset Maugham]]'s novel ''The Painted Veil'' (published as ''Malowana zas≈Çona'' in 1935, 2 vols.), were issued with the name of the translator fully identified. She also collaborated with [[Helena Niemirowska]] in the translation of [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s ''[[Puck of Pook's Hill]]'' (published as ''Puk'' in 1924) for which she provided verse translations. Despite their being overshadowed by the larger translations of whole novels, [[#Bibliography|Professor Araszkiewicz]] considered Arnsztajnowa's translations of those relatively small poetic fragments {{mdash}} and not the large bodies of prose translation {{mdash}} to be among her most notable achievements in the field.Feliks Araszkiewicz (see [[#Bibliography|Bibliography]]), p. 118. Her versions of Kipling's "Cities and Thrones and Powers" and "Harp Song of the Dane Women" (poems from ''Puck of Pook's Hill'') were published separately in [[literary magazine]]s.[[Rudyard Kipling]], "Grody i Trony w obliczu czasu..." (Cities and Thrones and Powers), tr. Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, ''Kamena'' ([[Che≈Çm|Che≈Çm Lubelski]]), vol. 1, No. 4, December 1933, p. 68. Rudyard Kipling, "Pie≈õ≈Ñ harfiarska du≈Ñskich niewiast" (Harp Song of the Dane Women), tr. Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, ''Kamena'', vol. 2, No. 7 (17), March 1935, p. 134. Similarly, her 1932 translation of a 12-verse excerpt from the French of ''[[Les Stances]]'' by [[Jean Mor√©as|Jean Mor√©as]] (Book 3; XII), beginning
''O toi qui sur mes jours de tristesse et d'√©preuve ''Seule reluis encor...''
reads better than the original:
''O, ty, co dni mych smutkom i zmaganiom ''blaskiem przy≈õwiecasz wytrwa≈Çym...''[[Jean Mor√©as]], "Przek≈Çady z poezyj J. Mor√©asa" (Translations of J. Mor√©as's Verses), ''[[Kurjer Lubelski]]'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 10, No. 4, 4 January 1932, p. 2. Includes two poems from ''Les Stances'' by Mor√©as in Arnsztajnowa's translation: Book 2, VII; and Book 3, XII. The latter poem reprinted in Jean Mor√©as, "Ze ''Stanc'' * * *" (From ''Les Stances'' * * *), tr. Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, ''Kamena'' ([[Che≈Çm|Che≈Çm Lubelski]]), vol. 3, No. 4 (24), December 1935, p. 73.
Always respectful of and ready to honour others for their achievement in their field, in 1899 Arnsztajnowa contributed to the ''[[Festschrift|liber amicorum]]'' for [[Aleksander ≈öwiƒôtochowski]] on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of his editorial work, a sumptuously produced volume that opens with her poem "Grajek" (The Fiddler; from the ''Poezye'' of 1895).Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, "Grajek" (The Fiddler); in: ''"Prawda": ksiƒÖ≈ºka zbiorowa dla uczczenia dwudziestopiƒôcioletniej dzia≈Çalno≈õci Aleksandra ≈öwiƒôtochowskiego, 1870{{ndash}}1895'', [[Lviv|Lvov]], Ksiƒôgarnia H. Altenberga [etc.], 1899, pp. 1{{ndash}}8. Some of her tributes in verse, even when marked by a high level of artistic accomplishment, were entirely private, meant solely for the honouree. Her poem composed in tribute to the Polish geographer, [[Wac≈Çaw Na≈Çkowski]] (1851{{ndash}}1911), the father of the writer [[Zofia Na≈Çkowska|Zofja Na≈Çkowska]], on the occasion of the 25th anniversary of his scholarly work in January 1903, did not come to light until 55 years later, for example.Roman Rosiak, "Franciszka Arnsztajnowa w ho≈Çdzie Wac≈Çawowi Na≈Çkowskiemu" (Arnsztajnowa's Tribute to Wac≈Çaw Na≈Çkowski), ''Kamena'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 25, No. 19 (161), 15 October 1958, p. 3. Her patriotic feelings found expression in the contribution she made to the collective volume published by the Teachers' Union to commemorate the [[Wrze≈õnia#Wrze≈õnia school strike of 1901|school strikes]] in [[Partitions of Poland|Partitioned Poland]] mounted in protest against marginalization of Polish culture by the occupying powers;''Walka o szko≈Çƒô polskƒÖ: w 25-lecie strajku szkolnego'', ed. S. Drzewiecki, ''et al.'', [[Warsaw]], [n.p.; ''but under the imprint of the'' ZwiƒÖzki Nauczycielstwa Polskich Szk√≥≈Ç Powszechnych i ≈örednich], 1930, p. 294. while in 1935 Arnsztajnowa served on the editorial board of a commemorative volume for the [[Polish Military Organisation]], to which she contributed the keynote poem (on the theme of the [[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier|Unknown Soldier]]) serving as a motto for the publication.Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, [untitled poem]; in ''Pod sztandarem P.O.W.: szkice i wspomnienia zebrane dla uczczenia uroczysto≈õci po≈õwiƒôcenia sztandaru, ods≈Çoniƒôcia tablicy pamiƒÖtkowej ≈õ.p. p≈Çk. Mieczys≈Çawa Wiƒôckowskiego i po≈ÇƒÖczenia okrƒôgu siedleckiego ZwiƒÖzku Peowiak√≥w z okrƒôgiem lubelskim: Lublin w marcu 1935 roku'', ed. F. Arnsztajnowa, ''et al.'', [[Lublin]], ZarzƒÖd Okrƒôgu i Ko≈Ço ZwiƒÖzku Peowiak√≥w, 1935, p. 5. Arnsztajnowa's patriotic fervour carried her so far as to contribute three technically accomplished, genuinely high-calibre poems {{mdash}} "Jego Imiƒô" (His Name), "O, Wodzu!" (O Leader!), and "Wodzowi-tw√≥rcy" (To the Leader-Creator) {{mdash}} to the collection of panegyrics in honour of [[J√≥zef Pi≈Çsudski]] published in 1924, two years before his [[May Coup (Poland)|''coup d'√©tat'' of May 1926]].Franciszka Arnsztejnowa [''[[sic]]'', not "Arnsztajnowa"], "Jego Imiƒô" (His Name); in ''J√≥zef Pi≈Çsudski w poezji: antologja'', [[Lublin]], Dom Wydawniczy Franciszek G≈Çowi≈Ñski i S-ka, 1924, pp. 3{{ndash}}4. ''[[Id.]]'', "O, Wodzu!" (O Leader!), in: ''[[ibid.]]'', p. 5. ''[[Id.]]'', "Wodzowi-tw√≥rcy" (To the Leader-Creator), in: ''[[ibid.]]'', p. 6. Among the 33 contributors to the collection (some of them not established poets), only the names of [[J√≥zef Czechowicz]], [[Jan Lecho≈Ñ]] and [[Kazimierz Przerwa-Tetmajer|Kazimierz Tetmajer]] stand in the same rank with Arnsztajnowa's. After the ''coup d'√©tat'' of May 1926, during a visit to Lublin in June 1931 of Pi≈Çsudski's [[List of heads of state of Poland|figurehead president]], [[Ignacy Mo≈õcicki]], she wrote in poetic prose a fulsome welcome for him in a local newspaper ("whole streets are running out to Him with open arms while ancient city walls silvered by age reverberate with the Good News: hail Thou the visible manifestation of the Independence!", etc.).F. Arnsztajnowa, "Dostojnemu Go≈õciowi na powitanie" (Welcoming the Distinguished Guest), ''Ziemia Lubelska'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 27, No. 148, 3 June 1931, p. 2. ====Antisemitic attacks on Arnsztajnowa==== In 1910 and 1911 Arnsztajnowa was the object of a book boycott motivated by antisemitic sentiment and spearheaded by the [[Endecja]] circles.[[Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa]] (see [[:pl:Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa|Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa]]), "Na piƒôterku" (Up the Little Flight of Stairs), ''[[Kamena (magazine)|Kamena]]'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 27, No. 18 (208), 30 September 1960, pp. 1 & 4. As a first-hand testimonial, this is one of the major primary sources for the biography of Arnsztajnowa. In the summer of 1937 Arnsztajnowa, then a 72-year-old ''[[grande dame]]'' of [[Polish literature]] (a recipient of the Silver Laurel of the [[Polish Academy of Literature]] and a decorated veteran of the Polish war of independence), was the victim of [[antisemitic]] attacks from the Endecja literary circles connected with the [[literary magazine]] ''[[Prosto z mostu]]'' of [[Warsaw]], a publication billing itself in the masthead as an artistic-literary weekly, edited and published by [[Stanis≈Çaw Piasecki]] (1900{{ndash}}1941). In its edition of 25 July 1937 the magazine in question carried a quasi-anonymous racist and in parts [[Vulgarism|scurrilously]] [[Poetaster|versified]] polemic signed only "(st. p.)" (which would have been universally understood by readers to refer to Piasecki) in which Arnsztajnowa was called, sarcastically, the "erector of the edifice of the [[Polish language]]" (''[[sc.]]'', one of the primary forces shaping the mother tongue) without being Polish. Although other Polish writers of Jewish descent were held up to ridicule by name as well, Arnsztajnowa was selected for special treatment. "Consider this efflorescence of Polish speech from under the ''aegis'' of Arnsztajnowa", jeered the writer of the article, presenting his readers with a sentence taken out of context from one of Arnsztajnowa's articles (on the complex subject of the phenomenology of contemporary French culture), which was supposed to offend against linguistic norm (it had, in fact, a [[typographical error]] involving the omission of a single letter). The attack on Arnsztajnowa continued under the guise of an attack on [[Ludwik Fryde]] (1912{{ndash}}1942), despite his young age already a distinguished literary critic of Jewish descent, whose surname was altered to "frydek" so that it might rhyme with ''≈ºydek'' ("the little jew", the lower-case initials employed for their added insulting value) while the author went on: "so it is among us that every common-or-garden pederast, if he has talent, he bandies it about", etc.(st. p.) [''[[sic]]'': lower-case initials in parentheses], "Wycinanki" (Newspaper Cuttings), ''[[Prosto z mostu]]'' (see ''[[:pl:Prosto z Mostu|Prosto z mostu]]'') ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 3, No. 34 (142), 25 July 1937, p. 5. The title of the periodical, ''Prosto z mostu'', is a Polish [[idiomatic]] expression meaning "without beating about the bush", "straightforwardly", "point-blank". The incident generated a groundswell of support for her from the Polish [[reading public]], including an open letter signed by many writers and poets, some of whom also published individual expressions of support {{mdash}} as did, for example, [[J√≥zef ≈Åobodowski]], calling the attack "outrageous and revolting".[[J√≥zef ≈Åobodowski]], "W obronie zas≈Çugi" (In Defence of Merit), letter to the editor, ''[[Wiadomo≈õci Literackie]]'' (see ''[[:pl:Wiadomo≈õci Literackie|Wiadomo≈õci Literackie]]'') ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 14, No. 32 (718), 1 August 1937, p. 8. After ≈Åobodowski's protest published in the most prestigious literary journal of the [[Interbellum|interbellum epoch]], the ''[[Wiadomo≈õci Literackie]]'', Piasecki remained unrepentant, and a fresh antisemitic attack on Arnsztajnowa was printed with additional vitriol in the ''Prosto z mostu'' edition of 8 August 1937.st. p.) [''[[sic]]'': lower-case initials in parentheses, with the left parenthesis missing], "Wycinanki" (Newspaper Cuttings), ''[[Prosto z mostu]]'' (see ''[[:pl:Prosto z Mostu|Prosto z mostu]]'') ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 3, No. 37 (145), 8 August 1937, p. 8. The [[antisemitic]] and [[homophobic]] attack on Arnsztajnowa and others was originally authored by [[Jerzy Pietrkiewicz]] and published in the ultra-nationalist and antisemitic periodical ''[[My≈õl Narodowa]]'' ("National Thought"), but ''Prosto z mostu'' went beyond the text of the original racist [[pasquinade]] in its attempt to disseminate, defend and justify it.[[Jerzy Pietrkiewicz]], "W rozm√≥wnicy" (In the Chat Room), ''[[My≈õl Narodowa]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 17, No. 29, 18 July 1937, p. 458. [http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/publication?id=144548 (See online.)] For its part ''My≈õl Narodowa'' will continue its attack on Arnsztajnowa on other fronts, bemoaning (in its issue of 29 August 1937) "the pernicious Jewish dispensation (''gospodarka ≈ºyd√≥w'') in the field of literature" for which the evidence was to be the supposed falsification by Niemirowska and Arnsztajnowa of Kipling (through their alleged toning down or expurgation of antisemitic passages in the works of this author).T. R. [''[[sic]]'': anonymous article], "Nauka i literatura: ''Rocznik Literacki''" (Sciences and Literature: ''The Literary Annual''), ''[[My≈õl Narodowa]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), vol. 17, No. 35, 29 August 1937, p. 552. [http://www.wbc.poznan.pl/dlibra/publication?id=144548 (See online.)] ===Death=== Published sources differ on the circumstances of her death, but there is a consensus that she did not die in Lublin, all the sources citing the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] {{mdash}} a place where she had gone proudly ''and of her own accord'', "to be with everybody" {{mdash}} as either the place of her death or the place of her [[Deportation#Deportation in the Holocaust|deportation]] immediately before her death. In some accounts she would have died in the Warsaw Ghetto of an infectious disease ([[typhus]]);So, for example, [[Jaros≈Çaw Iwaszkiewicz]], ''Marginalia'', ed. M. Iwaszkiewicz, ''et al. '', [[Warsaw]], Interim, 1993, p. 11. {{ISBN|8385083286}}. according to other accounts she would have been violently murdered there by the [[Nazis]], or have taken poison out of despair after seeing her daughter, Stefanja (who in all accounts accompanied her in the Warsaw Ghetto), shot dead by the Nazis. In some sources she would have been murdered after having been deported from the Warsaw Ghetto to the [[Treblinka extermination camp]] (the most common narrative, but not invested with greater evidentiary credibility than the other versions).So, for example, [[Julian Krzy≈ºanowski]], ''Neoromantyzm polski: 1890{{ndash}}1918'', [[Wroc≈Çaw]], Zak≈Çad Narodowy im. Ossoli≈Ñskich, 1963, p. 343. Cf. August Grychowski, ''Lublin i Lubelszczyzna w ≈ºyciu i tw√≥rczo≈õci pisarzy polskich: od ≈õredniowiecza do 1968 r.'', [[Lublin]], Wydawnictwo Lubelskie, 1974, p. 266. ''Rozkwita≈Çy pƒÖki bia≈Çych r√≥≈º...: wiersze i pie≈õni z lat 1908{{ndash}}1918 o Polsce, o wojnie i o ≈ºo≈Çnierzach'', ed. A. Romanowski, vol. 1, [[Warsaw]], Czytelnik, 1990, p. 145. {{ISBN|8307019141}}. Most authorities agree that she died in 1942, at the age of 77, however one otherwise well informed writer cites 1943 as the year of her death.Roman Rosiak, "O Franciszce Arnsztajnowej" (About Franciszka Arnsztajnowa), ''Kamena'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 27, No. 4 (194), 29 February 1960, p. 7. The date of 1943 is again repeated in Tadeusz K≈Çak, "Poetka Ziemi Lubelskiej" (The Poetess of the Lublin Land), ''Kamena'', vol. 32, No. 8 (318), 1{{ndash}}15 May 1965, p. 6. In what is perhaps the most reliable eyewitness report, that of the poet [[Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa]] (1905{{ndash}}1968), at the moment of her death {{mdash}} during the mass murder of patients at a hospital near All Saints' Church in Warsaw where she lay ill {{mdash}} Arnsztajnowa had two books with her, Dante's ''[[Divine Comedy]]'' and her own collection of poetry published in 1932, ''Odloty'' ("Flying Away"), on the poetics of departure.[[Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa]] (see [[:pl:Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa|Hanna Mortkowicz-Olczakowa]]), "Na piƒôterku" (Up the Little Flight of Stairs), ''Kamena'' ([[Lublin]]), vol. 27, No. 18 (208), 30 September 1960, p. 4. (Mortkowicz-Olczakowa does not cite the date of Arnsztajnowa's death; she does state that Arnsztajnowa's daughter, Stefanja Mieczys≈Çawska, unlike her mother, died in the [[Warsaw Ghetto]] of disease.) Cf. [[Wac≈Çaw Gralewski]], ''Ogniste ko≈Ça'', [[Lublin]], Wydawnictwo Lubelskie, 1963, p. 37. [[Anna Kamie≈Ñska]], "Poetka Lublina: legenda, dwug≈Ços pokole≈Ñ", ''[[Tw√≥rczo≈õƒá]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), No. 10, 1969, pp. 111{{ndash}}112. Note: the Church of All Saints in the plac Grzybowski (Grzybowski Square) in Warsaw was one of the two Catholic churches within the Warsaw Ghetto limits [http://zmh.um.warszawa.pl/gg.htm (see "Historical Sites of Jewish Warsaw" online).] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209080626/http://zmh.um.warszawa.pl/gg.htm |date=9 February 2013 }} Cf. Barbara Engelking & Jacek Leociak, ''The Warsaw Ghetto: A Guide to the Perished City'', tr. E. Harris, [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven (Connecticut)]], Yale University Press, 2009, p. 278. {{ISBN|9780300112344}}, {{ISBN|0300112343}}. (This source identifies only one instance of patients' being killed within a [[Warsaw Ghetto]] hospital: the incident happened during the [[Warsaw Ghetto Uprising#January to April 1943|January Action]] of 18{{ndash}}21 January 1943, at the makeshift medical facility organized in a converted tenement house in the Gƒôsia Street ‚Ññ 6{{ndash}}8: see pp. 276{{ndash}}278.) Cf. [[Adam Czerniak√≥w]], "Dziennik getta warszawskiego (6 IX 1939{{ndash}}23 VII 1942)" (A Journal of the [[Warsaw Ghetto]], 6 September 1939{{ndash}}23 July 1942), ''[[Biuletyn ≈ªydowskiego Instytutu Historycznego]]'' ([[Warsaw]]), Nos. 3{{ndash}}4 (83{{ndash}}84), July{{ndash}}December 1972, p. 292 (Czerniak√≥w seems to confirm that Arnsztajnowa died in the [[Warsaw Ghetto|Ghetto]] along with another poetess, [[Henryka ≈Åazowert√≥wna]], 1909{{ndash}}1942; and the novelist [[Gustawa Jarecka]], 1908{{ndash}}1943). Cf. Aleksander B. Skotnicki, ''et al.'', ''Jewish Society in Poland: Customs and Participation in the Fight for Independence: Many Faces of Cracovian Jewry'', tr. J. Niedbal & K. Baran, [[Krak√≥w]], Wydawnictwo, 2009, p. 109. {{ISBN|9788361060765}}, {{ISBN|8361060766}}. ("She was killed in the ghetto [''[[sc.]]'' [[Warsaw Ghetto]]], in 1942 at the age of 77.": see page 109.) Arnsztajnowa's first book, ''Poezye'' (1895), published when she was 30, contains this reference to [[Dante Alighieri]]:
''I ja by≈Çem w piekle‚Ä¶ we ≈õnie, czy na jawie ''Niewiem‚Ä¶ lecz, zaprawdƒô, Danta piekie≈Ç krƒôgi ''MƒÖk takich nie mieszczƒÖ, nie szarpiƒÖ tak krwawie‚Ä¶''F. Arnsztajnowa, [untitled poem] (lines 1{{ndash}}3); in ''[[id.]]'', ''Poezye'', [[Warsaw]], Gebethner i Wolff, 1895, p. 85. Arnsztajnowa employs the [[I (pronoun)|authorial "I"]] in the masculine form ("ja by≈Çem", not "ja by≈Çam"). ___________________________ To hell I've also been‚Ä¶ in dream or waking hours Can't say‚Ä¶ but, forsooth, Dante's [[Inferno (Dante)#The nine circles of Hell|infernal circles]] Contain not such torment as bloodily overpowers‚Ä¶
===Postscript=== Franciszka Arnsztajnowa was decorated by the government of the [[Second Polish Republic]] with the [[Cross of Valor (Poland)|Cross of Valour]] (''Krzy≈º Walecznych''), the [[Cross of Independence]] (''Krzy≈º Niepodleg≈Ço≈õci''), as well as the Knight's Cross (''Krzy≈º Kawalerski'') of the [[Order of Polonia Restituta]], one of the country's highest [[Order (decoration)|honours]]. She was the recipient of the Silver Laurel of the [[Polish Academy of Literature]] in 1936. She has a street named after herself in [[Lublin]], the '''ulica Franciszki Arnsztajnowej'''. ==Works== ===Poetry=== *''Poezye'' (1895) *''Poezye: serya druga'' (1899) *''Archanio≈Ç jutra'' (1924) *''Odloty'' (1932) *''Stare kamienie'' (1934) ===Drama=== *''Widmo: Ballada w I akcie'' (1905) *''Luxoniolo'' (1911) ==Bibliography== *[[Feliks Araszkiewicz]], ''Refleksy literackie: studja, szkice, notatki'', [[Lublin]], [Towarzystwo Przyjaci√≥≈Ç Nauk w Lublinie], 1934, pages 113{{ndash}}121. *Ewa ≈Åo≈õ, ''Franciszka Arnsztajnowa, 1865{{ndash}}1942'', [[Lublin]], Muzeum Lubelskie, Oddzia≈Ç im. J√≥zefa Czechowicza, 1988. *Micha≈Ç Doma≈Ñski, entry ''[[s.v.]]'' "Arnsztajnowa", in: ''S≈Çownik biograficzny miasta Lublina'', vol. 1, ed. T. Radzik, ''et al.'', [[Lublin]], Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu Marii Curie-Sk≈Çodowskiej, 1993, pages 15ff. {{ISBN|8322705646}}. ==See also== {{commons category}} *[[√âmile Meyerson]] *[[J√≥zef Czechowicz]] *[[J√≥zef ≈Åobodowski]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20130416085131/biblioteka.teatrnn.pl/dlibra/Content/25148/frania+arnstzajnowa_fot.+ze+zbior%C3%B3w+WBP+im.+H.+%C5%81opaci%C5%84skiego+(rkps+2156,+k.+301).jpg A photograph of Arnsztajnowa in her youth.] *[https://archive.is/20130416091928/biblioteka.teatrnn.pl/dlibra/Content/25146/Franciszka+Arnsztajnowa+(od+lewej)+z+rodze%C5%84stwem_fot.ze+zbior%C3%B3w+rodziny+Anne-Cathrine+Emilem+Meyersonem+i+Henriett%C4%85.jpg A photograph of Arnsztajnowa with her siblings]: the French philosopher √âmile Meyerson, her brother, is in the middle, her sister Henrietta on the right. *[https://archive.is/20130416164521/http://biblioteka.teatrnn.pl/dlibra/Content/25147/Franciszka+Arnsztajnowa_ze+zbior%C3%B3w+WBP+im.+H.+%C5%81opaci%C5%84skiego+(rkps+2156,+k.+297).jpg A photograph of Arnsztajnowa in her mature period.] *[http://biblioteka.teatrnn.pl/dlibra/Content/13321/200803041448000.25.17.jpg A photograph showing Arnsztajnowa in 1939 among a group of writers.] (Arnsztajnowa is third from the left.) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304204609/http://www.sztetl.org.pl/getfile2.php?class=image&m=&x=1000&y=800&id=53627 Commemorative plaque] on the town house (''kamienica'') in the ulica Z≈Çota No. 2 in Lublin that was owned by Arnsztajnowa. The inscription reads: "IN THIS HOUSE | BETWEEN THE YEARS 1899 and 1934 THERE LIVED | FRANCISZKA ARNSZTAJNOWA | POET | INDEPENDENCE ACTIVIST | CO-FOUNDER IN 1932 | OF THE WRITERS' UNION IN LUBLIN || ON THE 65TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE WRITERS' UNION". {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arnsztajnowa, Franciszka}} [[Category:1865 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:People from Lublin]] [[Category:People from Lublin Governorate]] [[Category:Polish Jews]] [[Category:English‚ÄìPolish translators]] [[Category:Jewish poets]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of Polonia Restituta]] [[Category:People who died in the Warsaw Ghetto]] [[Category:Polish civilians killed in World War II]] [[Category:19th-century Polish dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:Polish feminists]] [[Category:Polish Military Organisation members]] [[Category:Polish people of World War I]] [[Category:Polish women poets]] [[Category:Polish suffragists]] [[Category:Polish translators]] [[Category:Polish-language writers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Independence]] [[Category:Recipients of the Cross of Valour (Poland)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Polonia Restituta]] [[Category:Translators to Polish]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Poland]] [[Category:Polish people who died in Treblinka extermination camp]] [[Category:Jewish feminists]] [[Category:Polish women dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:20th-century Polish dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:20th-century translators]] [[Category:19th-century Polish women writers]] [[Category:19th-century Polish poets]] [[Category:20th-century Polish poets]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Hasmukh Baradi | image = Hasmukh Baradi 2010.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | caption = Baradi in 2010 | birth_name = Hasmukh Jamnadas Baradi | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1938|12|23}} | birth_place = [[Rajkot]], [[Gujarat]], India | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=y|2017|2|4|1938|12|23}} | death_place = [[Ahmedabad]], Gujarat, India | occupation = playwright, theater artist and theater | language = [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] | residence = | nationality = [[India]]n | education = Master of Arts | Alma_mater = | period = | movement = | notableworks = {{plainlist| * ''History of Gujarati literature'' * ''Raino Darpanrai'' }} | spouse = | children = Manvita Baradi | awards = | signature = Hasmukh Baradi autograph.svg | years_active = }}
'''Hasmukh Jamnadas Baradi''' (23 December 1938 - 4 February 2017) was a [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] playwright, theater artist and theater critic from [[India]].
==Biography== Baradi was born on 23 December 1938 in [[Rajkot]]. After completing his primary and secondary education in Rajkot, he received a diploma in theater direction from Saurashtra Sangit Natak Academy in 1961. Afterwards, he joined the [[Gujarat University]], where he earned a Bachelor of Arts in 1964 in English literature and [[Sanskrit]]. He received a Master of Arts in Theater History from [[Russian Academy of Theatre Arts|Lunacharsky State Institute for Theatre Arts]], [[Moscow]] in 1972.<ref name="Gujarati Vishwakosh">{{Cite book|title=‡™ó‡´Å‡™ú‡™∞‡™æ‡™§‡´Ä ‡™µ‡™ø‡™∂‡´ç‡™µ‡™ï‡´ã‡™∂|trans-title=Gujarati Encyclopedia|first=Dhirubhai|last=Thaker|author-link=Dhirubhai Thaker|publisher=[[Gujarati Vishwakosh|Gujarati Vishwakosh Trust]]|location=Ahmedabad|year=2000|volume=13|pages=361‚Äì362}}</ref> From 1959 to 1964, he worked as a playwright at [[All India Radio|Aakashvani]] in [[Vadodara]] and Rajkot.<ref name="GSP">{{cite web | title=‡™∏‡™µ‡™ø‡™∂‡´á‡™∑ ‡™™‡™∞‡™ø‡™ö‡™Ø: ‡™π‡™∏‡™Æ‡´Å‡™ñ ‡™¨‡™æ‡™∞‡™æ‡™°‡´Ä, ‡™ó‡´Å‡™ú‡™∞‡™æ‡™§‡´Ä ‡™∏‡™æ‡™π‡™ø‡™§‡´ç‡™Ø ‡™™‡™∞‡™ø‡™∑‡™¶ | website=Gujarati Sahitya Parishad | url=http://www.gujaratisahityaparishad.com/prakashan/sarjako/savishesh/Savishesh-Hasmukh-Baradi.html | language=gu | access-date=1 July 2018}}</ref>
He died on 4 February 2017 in [[Ahmedabad]].<ref name="The Times of India 2017">{{cite web | title=Playwright Hasmukh Baradi passes away | website=The Times of India | date=2017-02-05 | url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/playwright-hasmukh-baradi-passes-away/articleshow/56977548.cms | access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref> His daughter, Manvita Baradi, is a director, theater teacher, and architect in Ahmedabad.<ref name="Theatre Media Centre">{{cite web | title=Theatre Training Institute - Ahmedabad | website=Theatre Media Centre | url=https://www.theatremediacentre.com/trustees | access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref>
==Works== Baradi attempted a fusion of tradition and modernity in his plays.<ref name="ModiTrivedi2006">{{cite book|author1=Chinu Modi|authorlink1=Chinu Modi|author2=Darshana Trivedi|title=Two Plays: Aurangzeb, Naishadhrai|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9CZnAAAAMAAJ|year=2006|publisher=[[Gujarat Sahitya Academy]]|location=Gandhinagar|page=V}}</ref> He ran the Garage Studio Theater, which performed in [[Bhavai]] theatrical style, a traditional folk theatrical form particularly common in Western India. He wrote many plays within the Bhavai form which delved on topics of social reforms.<ref name="Sinha2004">{{cite book|author=Biswajit Sinha|title=Folk theatre|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UzEbAQAAIAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Raj Publications|isbn=978-81-86208-35-9|page=41}}</ref>
Baradi wrote ''Kalo Kamlo'' ({{abbr|lit.|literally}} Black Blanket), an experimental psychological play which he had published in 1975, and was translated into [[Hindi]] in 1980 as ''Kala Kambal''. He also wrote ''Raino Darpanrai,'' an adaptation of ''[[Raino Parvat]]'', as well as ''Baradina Be Natako'' (1984), ''Janardan Joseph'' (1985), ''Pachhi Shebaji Bolia'', ''Jashumati Kankuvati'', ''Eklu Aakash ane Bija Natako'', ''Tame Aanathi Ramtata'' and ''Akhu Aikhu Farithi''. In addition, Baradi translated ''[[Uncle Vanya]]'' by [[Anton Chekhov]] into Gujarati as ''Vanya Mama'' (1983).<ref name="GSP"/><ref name="Thakar1999">{{cite book|last=Thaker|first=Dhirubhai P.|authorlink=Dhirubhai Thaker|title=Glimpses of Gujarati literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H3NjAAAAMAAJ|year=1999|publisher=Gujarat Sahitya Akademy|location=Gandhinagar|isbn=81-7227-061-5|pages=38, 93}}</ref><ref name="MukherjeeKothari1995">{{cite book|author1=Bimal Mukherjee|author2=Sunil Kothari|author3=Ananda Lal|title=Rasa: Theatre and inema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dfsLAQAAMAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Anamika Kala Sangam|location=Kolkata|page=131}}</ref>
In 1983, Baradi wrote ''Natak Sarikho Nadar Hunnar'' (1983), a work of theater criticism.<ref name="GSP"/> He also wrote ''Gujarati Theaterno Itihas'', a literary history of Gujarati theater, which was translated into English by Vinod Meghani as ''The History of Gujarati Theater'' in 2004.<ref name="Kothari2005">{{cite book|author=Rita Kothari|authorlink=Rita Kothari|title=Translating India: The Cultural Politics of English|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I_Ceg7sfYIoC&pg=PA91|date=20 December 2005|publisher=Foundation Books|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-81-7596-305-4|page=91}}</ref>
==Awards== Baradi received the [[Narmad Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1987 for writing ''Raino Darpanrai'' (1986), and received [[Kumar Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1981 for his overall contributions to Gujarati theater.<ref name="Gujarati Vishwakosh"/>
