revision.text:
{{Use Indian English|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:Telo de Mascarenhas in 1940s.jpg|thumb|alt=Telo de Mascarenhas in the 1940s|Mascarenhas as a young man]]
'''Telo de Mascarenhas''' (born 23 March 1899 at [[Mormugao]] Harbour, Goa 1899, died 1979) was an author, a poet, a journalist and eminent freedom-fighter from [[Goa]].
==Biography==
In 1920 he travelled to Portugal to study, graduating in law from the [[University of Coimbra]] in 1930 (where he was taught by [[Ant√≥nio de Oliveira Salazar|Salazar]] amongst others). During this period he founded Lisbon's [[Centro Nacionalista Hindu]] (in 1926) and the periodical ''[[√çndia Nova]]'' (alongside [[Adeodato Barreto]] and other √©migr√© Goan intellectuals). Through the 1930s and 1940s, Mascerenhas worked in the Portuguese judicial system, first in the [[Algarve]] and then in the [[Alentejo]].<ref>Paul Melo e Castro, ''Lengthening Shadows'', 2 vols (Salig√£o, India: Goa, 1556, 2016), I p. 27.</ref>
After India's independence from Britain in 1948, Mascerenhas returned to the Subcontinent and actively participated in [[Goa Liberation Movement]]. Although he spent some time in Goa, he was forced into exile and spent the years 1950-58 in [[Bombay]]. During his years of exile in [[Bombay]], he published clandestinely ''Ressurge Goa'', a political newspaper from 1950 to 1959. Returning to Goa in 1959, he was arrested, and the Portuguese rulers deported him to [[Portugal]] where he was jailed, first in [[Aljube]] and then in [[Caxias, Oeiras|Caxias]]. Some years after the [[Indian annexation of Portuguese India|liberation of Goa]] he was released by the Government of Portugal in 1970 in exchange for the release of the Goan [[Chico Monteiro|Padre Francisco 'Chico' Monteiro]], who had been placed under house arrest by the Indian authorities for refusing to give up his Portuguese nationality.<ref>Paul Melo e Castro, ''Lengthening Shadows'', 2 vols (Salig√£o, India: Goa, 1556, 2016), I p. 27.</ref>
On his return to Goa from Portugal in 1970, he founded the [[C√≠rculo de Amizade Indo-Portuguesa]] (the Indo-Portuguese Friendship Society)<ref>Paul Melo e Castro, ''Lengthening Shadows'', 2 vols (Salig√£o, India: Goa, 1556, 2016), I p. 27.</ref> and restarted ''Ressurge Goa'' as a cultural and political paper.
==Works==
Mascerenhas was a prolific poet in Portuguese and also did a [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] translation of the autobiography of [[Mahatma Gandhi]] and of many novels by [[Tagore]].
=== Poetry in Portuguese ===
Mascerenhas published two volumes of poetry: ''Poemas de Desespero e Concola√ß√£o'' (Poems of Despair and Consolation, 1971) and ''Ciclo Go√™s'' (Goan Cycle, 1973).
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722230226/https://elgg.leeds.ac.uk/smlpmmec/weblog/19425.html Dois Poemas] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722230254/https://elgg.leeds.ac.uk/smlpmmec/weblog/19715.html As Sementeiras] *[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/09/telo-de-mascarenhas-primavera-chegou.html A Primavera Chegou]
===Prose Writing in Portuguese===
Mascarenhas published an English-language autobiography, ''When the Mango-Trees Blossomed'', in 1975. In it Mascarenhas claims to have written a novel and a novella during his incarceration in Portugal. The novel, ''Jogos Malabares'' (Malarbar Games), which he had to hide from the prison authorities, appears to have been lost. The novella was his ''Sinfonia Goesa'', written in 1962 while Mascerenhas was imprisoned in [[Cadeia do Aljube|Aljube gaol]]. Though it was never published in its entirety, several fragments saw the light of day in the post-Liberation Portuguese-language press. Some of Mascarenhas's writing has been published in English translation.<ref>Paul Melo e Castro, ''Lengthening Shadows'', 2 vols (Salig√£o, India: Goa, 1556, 2016), I pp. 27-28 (quoting p. 28); II pp. 5-17.</ref>
*[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/10/telo-de-mascarenhas-cronica-de-viagem.html Cr√≥nica de Viagem a Bombaim]
== External References == *[https://books.google.com/books?id=m2FmAAAAMAAJ&q=Telo+Mascarenhas&dq=Telo+Mascarenhas Bio entry on Mascarenhas] *[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/03/telo-de-mascarenhas-obituary-1979.html Obituary of Telo de Mascarenhas (in Portuguese)] *[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/03/telo-de-mascarenhas-o-nosso-passado.html Text by Mascarenhas recollecting his political past (in Portuguese)] *[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/06/telo-de-mascarenhas-carta-de-rendicao.html Mascarenhas memories of the Liberation of Goa as accompanied from his prison cell (in Portuguese)] *[http://archiveofgoanwritinginportuguese.blogspot.com/2011/09/eduardo-pereira-de-andrade-doutor-telo.html Poem dedicated to Mascarenhas by Eduardo Pereira de Andrade (in Portuguese)]
==References==

{{For|the rapper|Tone L≈çc}} '''''ToneLoc''''' was a popular [[war dialing]] computer program for [[MS-DOS]] written in the early to mid-1990s by two programmers known by the [[pseudonym]]s Minor Threat ([[Chris Lamprecht]]) and Mucho Maas. The name ToneLoc was short for "Tone Locator" and was a [[word play]] on the name of the [[rapping|rap]] artist known as [[Tone L≈çc]].
ToneLoc took advantage of the extended return codes available on [[US Robotics]] modems (e.g., ATX6<ref>{{cite web|title=5637 58K Users' Guide|url=http://www.usr.com/support/5637/5637-ug/ref_data.html|publisher=3COM|accessdate=10 January 2013}}</ref>) to detect dial tones upon dialing a number and to detect when a human answered the phone in addition to scanning for other modems. Detection of voice numbers sped up the scanning process by disconnecting upon detecting a human instead of timing out waiting for a modem carrier signal. The detection of a [[dial tone]] after dialing a number allowed for users to search for poorly secured extenders which could be used to divert calls through.
On April 17, 2005, the [[source code]] for ''ToneLoc'' was released.
==See also== *[[WarVOX]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.oldskoolphreak.com/etc/TL110SRC.ZIP ToneLoc v1.10 source code] *[http://www.textfiles.com/hacking/tl-user.txt ToneLoc v0.98 User Manual] *[https://archive.org/details/20040130-bbs-mthreat Interview with Minor Threat, ToneLoc's author], part of ''[[BBS: The Documentary]]''
[[Category:DOS software]] [[Category:Phreaking]] [[Category:Telephony]]
{{DOS-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer |name = Victor S√©jour |image = Victor S√©jour.jpg |image_size = 150 |caption = |birth_name = Juan Victor S√©jour Marcou et Ferrand |birth_date = {{Birth date|1817|6|2|df=y}} |birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1874|9|20|1817|6|2|df=y}} |death_place = [[Paris]], France |occupation = Writer, novelist, playwright |genre = [[Fiction]] |period = }}
'''Juan Victor S√©jour Marcou et Ferrand''' (2 June 1817 ‚Äì 20 September 1874) was an American expatriate writer who worked in France. Though mostly unknown to later American writers, his [[short story]] "[[Le Mul√¢tre]]" ("The [[Mulatto]]") is the earliest known work of fiction by a Creole author.<ref name="Norton">Victor S√©jour, Philip Barnard (translator). "The Mulatto." In [[Nellie Y. McKay]] and [[Henry Louis Gates]] (eds), ''The Norton Anthology of African American Literature'', Second edition, Norton, 2004. {{ISBN|0-393-97778-1}}</ref>
==Life== On 2 June 1817 Juan Victor S√©jour was born in [[New Orleans]] to Fran√ßois Marcou, a free mulatto father from [[Saint-Domingue]] (Haiti), and Eloisa Philippe Ferrand, a New Orleans [[quadroon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rCQJAQAAIAAJ&q=Victor+Sejour+saint-domingue&dq=Victor+Sejour+saint-domingue&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjEuMfrlLXJAhXGRyYKHSKKD8EQ6AEINDAE |title=Presence and Prestige: Africans in Europe : a History of Africans in Europe Before 1918 |page=194 |editor=Debrunner, Hans Werner |year=1979 |accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref> His parents were wealthy, and had him educated in a private school. At the age of nineteen he moved to [[Paris]] to continue his education and find work. There he met members of the Parisian literary elite, including [[Cyrille Bissette]], publisher of the black-owned journal ''La Revue des Colonies''. Bisette published "[[Le Mul√¢tre]]", S√©jour's first work, in 1837. The story of a loyal slave exacting revenge on his cruel master/father for the death of his wife, "Le Mul√¢tre" contains an indictment of [[New World]] [[slavery]] that is found in none of S√©jour's subsequent work.<ref name="Norton"/>
S√©jour then turned away from written fiction, and composed an ode to [[Napoleon]] in 1841 and the verse drama ''[[The Jew of Seville]]'' in 1844. The latter cemented his reputation as a [[playwright]]; he went on to write ''[[Richard III (1852 play)|Richard III]]'', a [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]-inspired costume drama about [[Richard III of England]], that became S√©jour's most acclaimed work. Towards the end of his life, however, S√©jour's plays fell out of favor, resulting in a decline in his status.
Written in French, "Le Mul√¢tre" had little effect on American literature, and was not even translated into [[English language|English]] until the late 20th century. Its condemnation of slavery, however, anticipates the work of later African-American writers such as [[Frederick Douglass]] and [[William Wells Brown]].<ref name="Norton"/>
==''The Brown Overcoat'' (1858)== S√©jour tended to leave racism discussions out of his plays, as exemplified by his play ''The Brown Overcoat''. It was a typical artificial comedy of the time period with witty comments and puns; however, it has nothing to do with race or greater issues of the world. This being so, S√©jour is still known as a great African-American playwright who led a successful career.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Black Theatre USA Revised and Expanded Edition, Vol. 1: Plays by African Americans, The Early Period 1847 to 1938|last=Shine|first=Ted|publisher=Free Press|year=1974|isbn=0-684-82308-X|location=New York, NY}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== *Victor S√©jour; Philip Barnard (translator). "The Mulatto." In [[Nellie Y. McKay]] and Henry Louis Gates (editors). ''The Norton Anthology of African American Literature'' Second edition, Norton, 2004. {{ISBN|0-393-97778-1}} *Victor S√©jour; Norman R. Shapiro (translator). ''The Jew of Seville''. University of Illinois Press, 2002. {{ISBN|0-252-02700-0}} *Victor S√©jour. "Le Mul√¢tre". ''Revue des Colonies'' Paris, 3:9 (March 1837), pages 376‚Äì392. *Brickhouse, Anna. ''Transamerican Literary Relations and the Nineteenth-Century Public Sphere''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2004. *Hatch, James V., and Ted Shine. ''Black Theatre USA: Plays by African Americans''. New York: Free, 1996. Print.
==Further reading== * Charles Edwards O'Neill, ''S√©jour: Parisian Playwright from Louisiana'' (University of Southwestern Louisiana, 1995), a book-length biography.
==External links== * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Victor S√©jour |sopt=w}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050925190549/http://www.centenary.edu/french/textes/mulatre.html "Le Mul√¢tre" (French)] * Piacentino, Ed. [http://southernspaces.org/2007/seeds-rebellion-plantation-fiction-victor-s%C3%A9jours-mulatto Seeds of Rebellion in Plantation Fiction: Victor S√©jour's "The Mulatto"]. ''Southern Spaces''. 28 August 2007 [http://southernspaces.org/2007/seeds-rebellion-plantation-fiction-victor-s√©jours-mulatto]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:S√©jour, Victor}} [[Category:1817 births]] [[Category:1874 deaths]] [[Category:Writers from New Orleans]] [[Category:American writers of Haitian descent]] [[Category:Louisiana Creole people]] [[Category:American expatriates in France]] [[Category:African-American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:African-American poets]] [[Category:19th-century French dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:French poets]] [[Category:French male short story writers]] [[Category:French short story writers]] [[Category:19th-century French writers]] [[Category:French-language writers]] [[Category:19th-century American dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:19th-century American poets]] [[Category:American male poets]] [[Category:American male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:American male short story writers]] [[Category:French male poets]] [[Category:19th-century American short story writers]] [[Category:19th-century American male writers]]

revision.text:
[[File:(ar-Rashid) dirham 170h.jpg|thumb|Dirham issued by ‚ÄòUlayya's half-brother ar-Rashid, 170 AH]] '''‚ÄòUlayya bint al-Mahdƒ´''' (160-210 AH/777-825 CE) was an [[Abbasid]] princess, noted for her legacy as a poet and musician. ==Biography== ‚ÄòUlayya was one of the daughters of the third [[Abbasid]] Caliph [[Al-Mahdi|al-Mahdi bi-'llah]] (r. 775‚Äì85), who reigned from 775 to his death in 785, and was noted for promoting poetry and music in his realm.{{cite book|first=Hilary |last=Kilpatrick |chapter=''MawƒÅlƒ´'' and Music |title=Patronate and Patronage in Early and Classical Islam |editor1=Monique Bernards |editor2=John Nawas |place=Leiden |publisher=Brill |year=2005 |pages=326‚Äì48}} Her mother was a singer and concubine called Makn≈´na (herself the ''jƒÅriya'' of one al-MarwƒÅnƒ´ya). It appears that, with her father dying early in her life, ‚ÄòUlayya was brought up by her half-brother [[Harun al-Rashid]] (r. 786-809). ‚ÄòUlayya was a princess, and, like her half-brother [[Ibrahim ibn al-Mahdi]] (779‚Äì839), a noted musician, and poet. It has been claimed that she surpassed her brother in skills and while 'not the only princess known to have composed poetry and songs', nonetheless 'the most gifted'.{{cite encyclopedia|first=Hilary |last=Kilpatrick |title=‚ÄòUlayya bint al-Mahdƒ´ (160-210/777-825) |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Arabic Literature |editor1=Julie Scott Meisami |editor2=Paul Starkey |place=London |publisher=Routledge |year=1998 |volume=II |page=791}} 'Much of her poetry consists of short pieces designed to be sung; in the ''mu·∏•dath'' style, it treats of love, friendship and longing for home, but also includes praise of HƒÅr≈´n, the caliph, celebration of wine and sharp attacks on enemies.' The main source for ‚ÄòUlayya's life is the tenth-century ''[[Kitab al-Aghani|KitƒÅb al-AghƒÅnƒ´]]'' of [[Abu al-Faraj al-Isfahani|Ab≈´ ‚Äôl-Faraj al-I·π£fahƒÅnƒ´]].al-I·π£fahƒ´nƒ´, Abu l-Faraj, ''KitƒÅb al-aghƒÅnƒ´'', DƒÅr al-Fikr, 21 parts and Index in 9 vols., equivalent to the edition Kairo 1322/1905‚Äì5. This and other sources tend to portray ‚ÄòUlayya as an accomplished woman who could readily hold her own in court society, but who tended to shy from too prominent a role in public life. She was wealthy and clearly possessed slave-girls, and had an intimate relationship with her powerful brothers; although there is little evidence of her communing with religious scholars, 'various reports in ‚ÄòUlayya's ''tarƒÅjim'' refer to her piety and adherence to ritual obligations'.{{cite journal|first=Matthew S. |last=Gordon |title=The Place of Competition: The Careers of ‚ÄòArƒ´b al-Ma‚Äôm≈´nƒ´ya and ‚ÄòUlayya bint al-Mahdƒ´, Sisters in Song |journal=‚ÄòAbbasid Studies: Occasional Papers of the School of ‚ÄòAbbasid Studies, Cambridge, 6‚Äì10 July 2002 |editor-first=James E. |editor-last=Montgomery |place=Leuven |publisher=Peeters |year=2004 |pages=61‚Äì81}}{{rp|66‚Äì68, 74}} ‚ÄòUlayya was married to an ‚ÄòAbbƒÅsid prince, but 'love-poems of her addressed to two slaves have been preserved'. One of the best known anecdotes about her concerns
her relationship with a member of al-Rashƒ´d's palace staff, a ''khƒÅdim'' named ·π¨all, with whom she would correspond in verse. When al-Rashƒ´d forbids her from uttering his name, she follows his order to the letter even when it precludes her from uttering a line of ''[[Al-Baqara|S≈´rat al-Baqara]]'' in which the term ''·π≠all'' occurs. When the caliph learns of this, he is swayed and presents ·π¨all to her as a gift. In this case, her piety become the means to winning a quite worldly reward.{{rp|77}}
==Poetry== As example of ‚ÄòUlayya's poetry is: ::I held back my love's name and kept repeating it to myself. ::Oh how I long for an empty space to call out the name I love.Abdullah al-Udhari, ''Classical Poems by Arab Women'' (London: Saqi, 1999), p. 110. ==Editions== * al-·π¢≈´lƒ´, Ab≈´ Bakr, ''Ash‚ÄòƒÅr awlƒÅd al-khulafƒÅ‚Äô wa-akhbƒÅruhum'', ed. by J. Heyworth Dunne, 3rd edn (Beirut: DƒÅr al-Masƒ´ra, 1401/1982), pp. 64‚Äì76. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Arabic literature}} {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{DEFAULTSORT:'Ulayya bint al-Mahdi}} [[Category:777 births]] [[Category:825 deaths]] [[Category:Medieval women poets]] [[Category:Abbasid-period poets]] [[Category:Abbasids]] [[Category:Arabic-language women poets]] [[Category:Arabic-language writers]] [[Category:8th-century women writers]] [[Category:9th-century Arabic writers]] [[Category:8th-century deaths]] [[Category:9th-century women writers]] [[Category:9th-century deaths]] [[Category:Umayyad-period poets]] [[Category:Women of the Abbasid Caliphate]] [[Category:9th-century Abbasid people]] [[Category:8th-century Arabic poets]] [[Category:9th-century Arabic poets]] [[Category:8th-century Arabic writers]]
